Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6411, file 841-5, part 3)
Dear Sir:

I have received an application from Mr. Indian Agent Strang for authority to expend the sum of approximately $110.00 to fence the grounds of the Shalalth Indian Day School, which amount covers the cost of materials and labour.

An item was included by the Agent in the 1941-42 Lytton Agency Estimates to provide for this expenditure. It is not known, however, just what provision has been made by the Department in this connection, and I shall be obliged if you will kindly advise me regarding same.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, if you consider it necessary to fence the grounds of the Seton Lake Indian Day School you may arrange for having this work done. It is understood that the total cost will not exceed $110.00. When forwarding the account you should attach to it a copy of your purchase order.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
Sir,

I beg to forward herewith a letter from Miss Mary Winter, teacher at Seton Lake Indian Day School, Shalalth, B.C., in which she requests a further allowance for hot drinks, etc. for mid-day meals at the school during the month of June.

In previous years these provisions have been allowed up to the end of the school term in June and owing to the destitute condition of most of the Indians sending their children to the day school and their inability to supply the needed food for the children's lunches, I would respectfully request the Department to consider allowing the $5.00 for the month of June as requested by Miss Winter. Some of the school children have to walk several miles to school and warm nourishing drinks are very helpful in maintaining the children's resistance to disease.

Your obedient servant,

A. Strang,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

RS.
enc.
Seton Lake Indian School,
Shalalth, B.C.

May 26, 1941

A. Strang Esq.,
The Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Strang:

I would like to request you for a renewal of the five dollar grant for lunches for the month of June, for this school. The reason is that I have noticed a number of the children with only dry bread for their lunch. This will cause malnutrition and make sickness and diseases likely to break out amongst them. We have already had an epidemic of measles since the grant closed at the end of March.

Hoping you will find it possible to renew this grant for the one month.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6411, file 841-5, part 3)
Ottawa,
June 2, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 28th ultimo the Department will allow an amount of $5.00 for the purchase of supplies for midday meal purposes at the Seton Lake School for the month of June, 1941.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. A. Strang,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Sir:

Re: Seton Lake School Building

I have received the following letter from Miss Mary Winter, Teacher, Seton Lake Indian Day School, Shalalth, dated March 23rd:

"I was informed that my predecessor, who was in charge of the Seton Lake School at the time the new building was being erected, had stated that the contractors had promised to completely redecorate the school inside and out, within a year after its erection. There was to be no charge for this as it was contained in the original contract. I hope you will take this matter up with the contractors."

This is probably only a local rumour as there does not appear to be anything about it in my copy of the contract. However, it is just possible that there may have been some such understanding between the contractor and the Dominion Public Works Department, which my records do not show.

I am therefore submitting this report to you on the matter, in duplicate, in case you wish to have someone look further into it.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

I desire to refer to your memorandum of March 2, 1940, on the completion of the erection of the Seton Lake Indian Day School. Indian Agent Strang advises me that he has received the following letter from Miss Mary Winter, teacher of this school at the present time:

"I was informed that my predecessor, who was in charge of the Seton Lake School at the time the new building was being erected, had stated that the contractors had promised to completely redecorate the school inside and out, within a year after its erection. There was to be no charge for this as it was contained in the original contract. I hope you will take this matter up with the contractors."

Neither the Indian Agent nor ourselves have any knowledge of the above arrangement and quite possibly it is only a local rumour. However, I should appreciate your advising me definitely on this point in order that I may notify Mr. Strang.

Director.
Dr. McGill

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Indian Day School, Seton Lake, B.C.

With reference to your notation dated the 9th instant on the memorandum from Dr. McGill dated April 1st, relative to the above I may say that the school building was accepted on behalf of the Department by our engineer as fully complete, in accordance with the plans, specifications and provisions of the contract, on January 31st, 1940.

In this connection, Engineer Ramsden's certificate of completion, approved by Mr. Webb reads as follows:

"CERTIFICATE OF COMPLETION

"I hereby certify that the contract of Ira C. Jones to build and construct the Indian Day School at Shalalth, Seton Lake Indian Reserve, B.C. entered into in November 1939, has been carried out in full.

"H.T. Ramsden."

Dear Sir:

Re Mr. McArthur's suggestion of putting in a cook stove to provide practical cooking lessons for this Day School:

I am afraid under the present conditions it would be full of difficulties. Much more than the stove would be needed. There would have to be kitchen table, and kitchen equipment, dishes etc., pans, baking tins, sauce pans, also cooking materials, butter, fats, sugar and spices, all rationed or under priorities.

Bread could be baked, but a difficult matter in a building left vacant over night. Loaves baked the same day as set would often entail staying late at night. There is no lighting system.

There are at present only five or six girls who are old enough to benefit by such an outlay. These are bright and intelligent and can be helped by oral cooking lessons and taking home recipes to practice on in their own homes. There would be less waste and no friction as to whom is to benefit by the cooked food. Always a touchy matter with Indians.

Have already given oral lessons on cooking and diet, and have suggested they bring material to the school and I would supervise the mixing of ingredients.

I may say, as Field Matron up the coast, I made many attempts to teach practical cooking. As the teacher's residence was in the building, the obstacles that we have here were eliminated. But there was always the difficulty of supplies. It's almost impossible to persuade the Indians to provide even a few eggs. Should they provide one, they feel they are entitled to the whole cake.

I have for reference your letter of the 4th instant enclosing Inspector McArthur's report on the Seton Lake Indian Day School and requesting my comments on the observations contained in the above report.

I beg to advise you that with regard to the Inspector's indications under Vocational Education, a garden for this School is out of the question as there is no water available for irrigation purposes. Aside from this, owing to the fact that the school is closed during the months of July and August, when everyone, including the teacher, is away on holiday, the garden would be completely burned in the space of a week or so.

As to the installation of a cook stove in the school building, I beg to point out that no provision was made in the construction of the school for such purposes. This matter has been gone into several times with previous teachers and was considered impractical for the reason above given. Mrs. Marsden was asked last year to submit me a list of her requirements for sewing lessons and so far this information has not been forthcoming. I would point out that no teacher's residence was provided in the school for the reason that good accommodation was available within easy walking distance of the school.

In view of the fact that such accommodation still exists I see no reason for the Inspector's remark in this connection. The necessary quotation for the construction of a sand table for this school was obtained last year and the authority for the expense granted me. However, the carpenter concerned lost his material in a fire and as a consequence the table was not provided. Mrs. Marsden, since then, having failed to interest any other person in the construction of the table required.

I am of the opinion that Inspector McArthur's observations are made without due consideration of the lack of provision made in the design of the building for vocational training. In order to provide practical cooking lessons for the school, more than a cook stove would be required. A kitchen table, kitchen equipment including dishes, etc., would be required and at the present time, much of the material required for simple cooking is rationed or difficult to procure. Mrs. Marsden has informed me that she has been giving oral lessons in cooking and diet to those girls who are sufficiently old and has given them recipes on which to practise at home. Due to the above mentioned lack of
space, an oil stove has been placed in the school in order to prepare warm mid day meals for the pupils during the winter months. Mrs. Marsden avails herself of this opportunity to give the children what information she can in the way of demonstrating cleanliness and efficiency in the preparation of a simple meal.

I do not appear to have a copy on hand of your letter of July 21st, 1943, and in order to give the matter consideration I would much appreciate your forwarding me a copy of same.

(Sgd.) A. Strang.
Indian Agent.

Copied by M.)
A. Strong, Esq., Indian Agent, Lytton, B.C.

I received a call today from Mrs. Marsden, teacher of Shalalth Indian Day School, and she discussed a number of problems affecting her school, some of which are quite small and could, no doubt, be attended to without very much difficulty.

One of these was that there is no chain on the furnace drafts leading up into the classroom or whatever room is above the furnace, and it is necessary to make frequent trips from one end of the school and then back to the other end of the basement to adjust these drafts. She also pointed out that it would be a great advantage to have some screens for the windows with which I quite agree. No doubt, the adjustable screens that fit in underneath the windows would be suitable for the purpose. It was also pointed out that the furnace shoots the dust up into the school room and may be in need of cleaning out between the casing and the inner furnace. I do not know whether this could be done without a great deal of difficulty.

In the course of discussion of manual training for the school, it developed that there is something wrong with the flooring in the basement which she states becomes a "gooey mess" when damp. This is the first time this has been brought to my attention and I would appreciate your report.

Apparently the school desks have become loose in the joints and need a general tightening up. This should be attended to in order to avoid necessity of replacement as these desks are now quite hard to get.

Concerning the manual training, Mrs. Marsden thought that Mr. Hughes, the white school teacher, would be pleased to give manual training instruction to the boys for amount £2.00 a week and, if this could be arranged, it would appear to be quite reasonable and I would suggest your investigating the matter and advising me further. If Mr. Hughes is agreeable to undertaking this work for a reasonable sum, it will be necessary then to secure material with which to build benches in the basement and some wooden mats for the boys to stand on in order to keep their feet off the floor, and, of course, a number of manual training tools and material will also be necessary.
The question of domestic science instruction for girls as mentioned by the School Inspector was discussed, and if this work was to be carried on a kitchen stove in the basement would be necessary. This could be of a very inexpensive type but would, of course, require the construction of a chimney and is a subject on which I would like your report, giving some estimate of the cost of erecting a satisfactory chimney for this purpose. In connection with domestic science teaching, the question arose regarding the provision of a sewing machine and you could, no doubt, advise me whether you wish to recommend same.

The lack of domestic water at the school was also mentioned but I do not know what could be done about this unless it is possible to dig a well and install a pump, which is another matter regarding which you could advise me.

Mrs. Marsden has been closing the school when the Priest visited the Reserve and held services during school hours. She was informed very definitely that the only person outside of the Department at Ottawa who could authorize the closing of a school would be the doctor in case of an epidemic. She was shown the circular setting out the days school was to be open but she questioned our authority in the matter and stated she would see the Archbishop about it. Please see that the Department's instructions are adhered to. Probably a tactful chat with Father Fehlman will overcome future difficulty.

CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

During a brief visit to the Shalalth Indian Day School last fall, I found that water required at the school had to be drawn from Seton Lake and brought by bucket up a long steep hill to the school - a difficult task, especially in the winter.

On my return to Vancouver, I arranged with District Engineer Webb of the Surveys and Engineering Branch to have one of his Engineers look into the matter of providing a suitable water supply to this school. An investigation in this connection has now been made and a report submitted by Engineer J.A. Mackenzie, a copy of which has gone forward to Mr. T.S. Mills of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, Ottawa.

The scheme involves an outlay of $150.00 to change the position of the Neal Evans Transportation Company's storage tank from which the proposed supply is to be obtained, and a rate of $2.00 per month for the water. There is no way by which we could secure a suitable supply at less cost, and, as it is essential that the school be provided with this service, I would strongly recommend that the Department approve of the proposal. An early reply would be appreciated.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Shalalth Indian Day School
Seton Lake I.R.

In accordance with instructions I visited the Indian Day School at Seton Lake I.R. to investigate the water supply for the school.

Two sources of supply were investigated (1) a creek flows within a few yards of the school. However as the creek bed is wide and gravelly no water appears on the surface at the school. At this season water was found flowing 2,600 feet above the school. Although there was abundant water at this season, it is doubtful whether the supply would continue through the dry season. Cattle and horses use the stream for a watering place and the water would be subject to contamination.

(2) The second source of supply is water pumped from Seton Lake. At the present time Neal Evans Transportation Company supply their offices and workshops by pumping water to a 500-gallon tank from Seton Lake. The tank is not high enough to deliver water to the school. Neal Evans Transportation Company would be agreeable to supplying water to the school at a rate of $2.00 per month, provided the Indian Department would move the tank to a higher elevation, supply a float switch for the tank and make all the necessary connections. This work would cost $150.00.

As Neal Evans Transportation Company is a reliable concern, this arrangement is recommended provided that the rates are satisfactory to the Indian Department. The Neal Evans Transportation Company have agreed to submit this proposal in a letter if requested. It is estimated that fifteen gallons per day would supply the requirements of the school.

11th January 1946.

The following report has been received from Mr. Webb under date of January 8th:

"This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of Dec. 8, regarding above project. So far, owing to the fact that the Neal Evans Transportation Company were not favourably inclined to our connecting to their system during the severe weather conditions which now pertain, we have not proceeded with this project. As soon as weather becomes more favourable work will be put under way and completed.

"I have discussed with Provincial Water Rights Branch the question whether water license will be needed and on their advice have made arrangements for the obtaining of the necessary license.

"The Neal Evans Transportation Company are not inclined to enter into an agreement for a period of 10 years. I have discussed this matter with Indian Commissioner McKay, who considered that an agreement for a period of 5 years is all that could be expected. With this in mind, I am forwarding you herewith copy of letter from the Neal Evans Trans. Co., dated 2nd January, in which you will note that they would be satisfied with a 3 to 5 year agreement with a proviso that such agreement would be for such lesser period of time as the water system at Shalalth is operated by their Company. This latter suggestion was made by us to meet the objections of the Company to entering into an agreement which might bind them if at some future date they ceased to operate at Shalalth.

"Will you please advise at your earliest convenience as to whether or not the proposal made by the Company is agreeable so that I may acknowledge their letter."

A copy of letter from the Neal Evans Transportation Co., dated Jan. 2nd, is attached in duplicate. We believe that an agreement to deliver water to the School during a period of five years or during such lesser period as the water system is operated by the Company and to maintain the water rate at $2.00 per month for this period is as much as we can expect to obtain.

In the event of the sale of the assets of this Company it would be necessary to negotiate another agreement with the new owners, and if the use of the system should be discontinued by the Company, Indian Affairs would lose their water supply. If Indian Affairs are agreeable to this arrangement and ask us to draw up the agreement we will have the matter attended to.

Re: WATER SUPPLY - SHALALTH INDIAN DAY SCHOOL
SETON LAKE I. R. No. 1

Referring to your notation on copy of a memorandum from Indian Affairs dated 18th January, we are now in receipt of a letter from Mr. Webb dated February 5th in which the matter of an agreement with the Neal Evans Transportation Company is discussed as follows:

"This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of 1st February asking me to prepare and forward a draft agreement embodying the conditions and mentioning the water licences affected. As you know, we have no legal assistance here, and I do not feel we are capable of drawing up the legal document necessary in this case, or that an agreement, if drawn, will be signed by the Company.

"At present we have not yet received a water licence although preliminary arrangements have been made to obtain one. On Oct.23,1946, the Comptroller of Water Rights advised me that his records do not indicate that the Neal Evans Transportation Co. Ltd. holds any water licence for diversion of water from Seton Lake at or about Shalalth. I doubt if the company will look favorably on our demanding that they obtain one, especially as to dispose of water by sale may require them to take out a Class C water licence and might also necessitate them obtaining change in their memorandum of association as well as paying additional fees which they would be required to pay if they simply took out a licence for their own purposes. While I have no official advice, my understanding is that the province does not consider the cost warranted to insist on licences being taken out by the numerous parties who divert small quantities of domestic water from large lakes and rivers for what might be classed "Riparian rights", although such rights are not recognized by law in British Columbia, except under certain conditions.

"I have discussed this matter with the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, and he concurs that in view of the small investment by us, the fact that the Company are supplying water more as a convenience to us than as a business matter, and that they are only prepared to supply water while in business at Shalalth, we should simply get a letter from them setting forth what they are prepared to charge for fifty gallons per day. We have letters covering what they are willing to do, and might get these incorporated into one letter. As stated, I do not feel the Company would be justified in representing that the transportation is considerable expense if the school is to be supplied."

J. M. Wardle, Esq., Director,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Dept. Mines and Resources
Ottawa.
We believe that it is unnecessary to consider any action that would cause additional expense and trouble to the Neal Evans Transportation Company, as the benefits to accrue to the Company under the arrangement with Indian Affairs would not recoup these for such outlay. It seems correct that permission for the use by Indian Affairs, of water delivered through the Company system, would be in the nature of a favor and nothing should be done which might lead to reconsideration and cancellation of this privilege.

As the arrangements to date appear to have been handled from Mr. Webb's office, we suggest that he be authorized to acknowledge the letters of August 20th and January 2nd from the Company, and state that the conditions outlined in these two letters are accepted and no formal agreement will be executed.

We have consulted the Departmental Solicitor, who approves this arrangement. Will you please authorize this procedure.

[Signature]

CHIEF ENGINEER.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Water Supply, Shalalth Indian Day School, Seton Lake I.R. No. 1.

In accordance with your instructions of March, 1946, the water connection to the school on the school on the above reserve was completed.

The source of water supply is the Neal Evans Transportation Company's storage tank, which obtains water from the Seton Lake and serves the company buildings. To this storage tank was connected another tank at a higher elevation to supply the Indian School with water by gravity. Two taps were installed; one in the kitchen and one immediately outside.

The drain which was installed during the construction of the school was found faulty. It appears that the waste pipe from the sink ends underground immediately outside the building, instead of extending to an adjacent ravine approximately sixty feet away. This allows the waste to seep directly through the basement wall.

On a recent visit to the Seton Lake Indian Day School I found that the following repairs will be necessary before winter.

Weather strip for two doors, set in lock on the front door, putting up window blinds, desks to be set on strips, repair and put up storm windows, two toilets to be replaced. Sir:

When visiting Shalalth Day School last week, the teacher, Mr. Finnegan, took up with Mr. Gains and myself, the matter of providing a house to accommodate the teacher. I told him to get estimates on the lumber that it would require and he has now sent me an estimate of $250.25.

Mr. Finnegan has undertaken to be responsible for the erection, if the Department will provide the necessary material.

Mr. Gains and I talked this matter over and came to the conclusion that it certainly would be more satisfactory, if there was a house for the teacher, where he could stop and board himself or herself, as the case might be, as the only stopping house at the present time is Mr. Rebagliati's, which is certainly not very congenial.

We have, of course, to take into consideration the fact that whilst Mr. Finnegan is there the house will be very useful, but perhaps if there is a change of teachers, the next one might not want to back, still as long as things are as they are at present, I would like to recommend that a building be provided for this purpose.

Trusting that the Department will give this matter its earliest attention, as it is very necessary to get the building erected as soon as possible before the cold weather comes, if it is decided to build one.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING SEPTEMBER 30TH, 1945, ON LYTTON AGENCY

WELFARE AND TRAINING

Education:

Seton Lake Day School: The former Miss Blue has married, now being named Mrs. Hugh, and has returned as teacher of the above school. Her return for the last quarter indicates a good attendance and conditions at the school are satisfactory. I have not had an opportunity to visit this school since the opening. Arrangements have been made for a suitable supply of wood for the school and necessary drugs are being requisitioned. Arrangements are also under way for tuition in manual training for the pupils of the school and a requisition for necessary equipment and supplies has been submitted for approval.

A. Strang,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Mrs. Bertha Hugh, teacher of the Seton Lake Indian Day School has suggested that her husband, who is teacher of the Provincial white school at Shalalth, devote a short period of each week for instruction in manual training for the pupils of the Indian Day School and that she, in return, instruct the white pupils in domestic science. This proposal would appear to have considerable merit and is approved by the Provincial School Inspector and the Indian Agent. I would recommend that the Department approve of the arrangement.

It will be necessary to supply various tools and supplies to the Indian Day School, the cost of which should not exceed $80.00. If the proposal meets with the approval of the Department it would be appreciated if you would approve an expenditure of this amount from the B.C. Special Vote.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Bostock,

I was unable to answer your letter until I had seen the Bishop & heard from home as to the way our plans had been considered there. As you know we have a big Hospital at Lytton & attend to many Indians who may come in for treatment. Dr. Sarson is our visiting Surgeon & I am general Medical Superintendent but the work takes up so much of my time that I must give it up and we wish to have a medical man in charge who will also be responsible for the Indians of our Mission. I have applied to the S.P.C. and the S. P. C. K. at home through the Bishop asking them to make us a grant of £150 -0 -0 a year towards the salary of a regular fully qualified medical missionary & then I meant to write the Indian Department asking them to make a grant of $600-$600.00 per year towards the salary of a medical man in charge of this district from Spuzzum to Spences Bridge & from here to Foster's Bar-within 20 miles of Lillooet & also intended asking the Indian Department for an annual grant towards the medical supplies. These are the main features of what we have been trying to do & the home societies have favourably received our application and at their annual meeting in March will, we hope make us the grant we have asked for and send us one semi-anl.

I feel sure that this is the only way we can get the Indians properly attended to, you know how the general practitioner out here neglects his Indian work & attends to his white practice, & to avoid a chance of this sort of thing happening we practically make his stay here depend on his doing the Indian medical work thoroughly as if he neglects it we can withdraw the grant from the
Home Societies. I hope I have made this clear we shall be very glad if this meets your approval & you can further our application at Ottawa.

I do not know whether it would be right to ask the Department to make their annual grant payable also the Indian Hospital account so that the whole would then come from us. I doubt whether this could be done.

I have one other matter I wish to write to you about particularly in regard to the Nicola Indians on the Shulus Reserve. We have a school there and would like to put up a Hospital & a decent School with rooms attached for the teacher's to live in. I feel certain the best way to reach the Indians is to give them Day Schools on the Reserve with teachers who will visit the Reserves & help to teach cleanliness in their houses & also teach sewing, lace making & a few other useful things in sewing classes to the Indians generally, not only the young ones, teach the older women to cut out and make clothes, and so put them in the way of being independent & self reliant. The salary the Government pays the teachers is very small only $400.00 a year, but if they will help us in the buildings we will add to it & try and get thoroughly 60.00 teachers.

Then we want a Hospital there badly, the Indians have been so badly treated by white doctors generally that they have no confidence in them, and we intend that the Dr. shall have charge of the Hospital & that he makes weekly visits there, we shall always keep fully trained nurses there & the doctors in the Valley can always look after any patient they send in.

These buildings will cost in all between furniture land, pump house &c over $7000.00 I shall be glad if you will kindly go into it & if you can support my application will you help us in getting a grant from the Department towards the buildings. If we can get $3000.00 towards the Hospital & school it will make it possible for us to set about it this year.

If any of these plans are not clear I shall be very pleased to answer any questions in regard to them.

Yours sincerely

(Signed) Edward W. Hugh

Dear Sir:

I have gone into the matter of your letter very carefully with both the Rev. G.S. Benson and Mr. Indian Agent O'Gorman with regard to the attendance at the Shulus Indian Day School. Mr. Benson has already written to Mr. O'Gorman several times drawing his attention to the fact that the average daily attendance is not what it ought to be, and has asked his assistance to enforce a more regular attendance, and he and Mr. Benson and the Chief have made some visits to the various houses on the Reserve to try and insist on the parents sending their children to School regularly, so far without any success, and the attendance today is worse than ever as so many of the parents are away and have taken their children with them to various fishing places and Big Island. So my mind, and both Mr. Benson and Mr. O'Gorman agree with me, the only thing we can do is make an example of some of the parents and send to the Indian Industrial School most children who constantly refuse to attend the Day School. It is no use to keep on complaining that the Department will do nothing and then never do anything, like white people they naturally conclude that nothing will be done and pay no attention to what is said to them. Will you please enforce the act. I had hoped to see Mr. Inspector Comanahop but unfortunately whenever he has been in Lytton I have been away.

I can suggest no better system than the one set up now at Shulus. Mr. Benson is an Oxford graduate with some good experience as a teacher.

Very Reverend Sir,

The Department regrets very much to see that there has been no improvement in the attendance at the Sholus Day School, in fact there has been a falling off during the past quarter when the average for the three months was only 6.6.

As you are aware, the Department is paying a salary of $600.00 at this school, but, unless the Principal and his assistant can interest the Indians to a greater extent in sending their children to the school, it will hardly be possible to continue the payment of a grant to that extent.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ven. Archdeacon N.W. W. Pugh, M.A.,
Lytton, B.C.

Sir,

Dear Sir,

I saw Mr. Indian Agent Graham on Monday in regard to his letter to the Department notifying them of Miss Waghorn's resignation of the position of teacher at the Iey School on the Shulus Reserve. Miss Waghorn sent in her resignation to me and also to the Indian Agent who advised me to accept it as she was evidently a person hard to get on with. At the time I told him Miss Williams would take on the work at the School, apparently this fact slipped Mr. Graham's memory, and on the day he called at the School Miss Williams had gone into Merritt to see the Provincial Iey School there and so Mr. Graham did not meet her, and the Revd. F.E. Eteson was taking the School that afternoon. I have no desire to change the plan I laid before the Department when I made request for the grant towards the buildings, viz., "that the Principal should be a Clergyman holding a University degree and that he should also have someone else at the School with him." The Revd. F.E. Eteson is a Master of Arts of Oxford, and has had four years experience as a Teacher, while Miss Williams is a graduate of Ambleside Teachers College and also holds Certificates of the Royal Horticultural Society as a fully qualified Gardiner. I am most anxious that the Shulus Iey School should be a success and am prepared to do all I can to make it so, and I am quite sure that when the Inspector of Indian Schools, the Revd. W.F. Green sends in his report after his next visit, that the Department will feel the Shulus Iey School is at least up to the standard.

Yours very sincerely,

Sir,

I have the honor to report for the information of the Department that on the 19th of February I received a request from the Archdeacon of Yale, the Ven. E. W. W. Pugh, to go to Lytton, that he might consult with me regarding "Shulus" Indian Day School. So when in that Agency I went to Lytton on Feb. 25th., and had a long interview with Archdeacon Pugh.

The trouble at Shulus is between the teacher Miss. Waghorn, and the missionary in charge of the tribe, Rev. Mr. Eaton. Miss. Waghorn was engaged last October by the Right Rev. A. U. Be Fencier, Bishop of New Westminster, and sent to take charge of the school. At the close of the December quarter Mr. Eaton insisted that she should be entered in the report as Principal, and the real teacher, Miss. Waghorn, as assistant. She rebelled at this and in January sent in her resignation to Mr. Pugh. At first he refused to accept it, and wished her to reconsider the same. But as they continued to disagree the Archdeacon wrote Miss. Waghorn on Feb. 24th., the day before I arrived, accepting her resignation to take effect on February 28th. All admit that Miss. Waghorn is an excellent teacher, but it is important that there should be harmony between the teacher and the missionary working among the same people.

The Archdeacon now requests that the clergyman in charge, Rev. Mr. Eaton, be the acknowledged Principal of Shulus School, and will impart religious instruction, and have an assistant to teach. I have asked Mr. Pugh to make it clear to the clergyman that if he is Principal he will be expected to attend the school daily, and that we must look to him to be responsible for the proper running of the school, and for a reasonable average attendance.

Mr. Pugh assures me this shall be done, and a journal kept...
with the register for official inspection, stating what the Principal has done each day in the school.

I have the honor to remain

Your obedient servant

The degree I hold is Diploma of Licentiate L.Mus. M.I.C. of the Musical International College, London, Eng., received from the Principal Soni, M.Sott., Mus.Doc., Cantab; and for some time Lecturer at Trinity College Toronto.

My experience — I was a teacher at a College in England until 19 years of age, passed South Kensington and other Exams; after that was the Principal of a High School in Peterborough, Eng. For nearly 15 years I had a staff of Masters & Mistresses yet always prepared the Candidates for the Oxford Examinations myself also for the Musical Exams; and was very successful, not having a failure, many receiving distinction in Senior Honors 1st Class. Amongst my pupils were the late Bishop of Worcester (Mr. Parsons) nieces, Bishop Holmes' two daughters, & the daughters of J. McLean Esq., Sandringham. The Scholastic work of the latter pupils was often presented to Queen Alexandra so Her Majesty took an interest in their gifts when at Sandringham, & she graciously expressed her satisfaction, especially with the French, Painting & Music.

I am pleased to say, that many of the ten favored by my gifts are now employed either as Governesses abroad or getting their own living in England as Teachers. I have had several seniors to prepare for the Scholastic profession; one Miss E. Sanford (Rev. Sandford, q. Southwell) has a large School there with her Sister. I receive many grateful letters of thanks from those whom I helped in my Establishment. Owing to family bereavement I came out to Canada four years ago with Bishop Holmes who escorted me up.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to know if the Department will authorize an expenditure of $10.00 in materials for a sewing class of women or girls held one night a week in our schoolroom during the winter months by my wife. Last winter we had a very flourishing class of twenty or more who came to learn how to make their own clothes instead of buying them at a store. The teacher was a serious one last year but this year I doubt if we shall get any as every one is working for the war. I am sure you will agree that the work is both useful for the class and a big need as there is no good all round when it is most needed. After last year's effort was so well appreciated and backed up it would be a great pity if the thing was dropped.

Yours very truly,

I found the class room clean and orderly, and the teacher Mr Harwood (who, while not a trained teacher,) is in my opinion doing the very best possible under existing conditions.

The teacher has considerable difficulty in getting anything like a reasonable attendance of the children of school age, or even of those on the roll. He having to go from house to house every morning and after recess to gather them up.

There are some twenty (20) children of school age on that reserve, with seventeen (17) on the school roll; and only seven (7) in attendance on the day of my visit.

I visited the Shulus Indian Day school on the 23rd ultimo, now in charge of Mr. Jack Hardwood, a young man no doubt of good parts. Dear Mr. McLean:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th inst., No. 386204-1. I am afraid I am to blame about it.

I understand Mr. Fyall to tell me he had told Mr. Smith he was leaving, he married the Nurse at the hospital, and they left to take up work on his ranch in the Nicola Valley. I hoped to get a man who has a degree to take on the School but at the last minute he could not come. Then a man who had been a patient at the Hospital with Empyema, an old Malborough Public School man of excellent education asked me if he could get the job; he is hard up, with very little money only able to do the lightest work, he has a wife and ten children. I felt sorry for him and told him if he cared to go and see Mr. Cairns, the Inspector of Schools for the Province and he was willing for him to have the School it's right so far as I was concerned, he went and Mr. Cairns agreed to the appointment and Mr. Hooper took up the work. I am afraid I left it at that and quite forgot to inform Mr. Smith, as a matter of fact I really thought Mr. Cairns would have done so, that is really what happened, Mr. Cairns as I know now expected me to inform Mr. Smith. Please blame me in the matter and keep Mr. Cairns out of it when you write to Mr. Smith, I really am very sorry and will take care such a thing does not happen again. Poor Mr. Smith is awfully touchy and although I seem to have done all I can to remove his prejudices it seems no good. He has heard me tell the Head Nurse always to give him meals and a bed at the Hospital whenever he may find it a help to stay there rather than return to Merritt, but it is no good. In regard to consulting the Department I really did not know that I should do that, I did really think that after consulting with Mr. Cairns the whole thing was alright so far as I was concerned. I hope to be in Ottawa in September for me hard. With kindest regards and many sincere apologies,

Yours very sincerely,

Mr Fyall informed me that he was engaged and appointed to the position by the Ven. Archdeacon, and that he had lived in the Valley several years and had acquired a great deal of the Thompson language. I did not question him as to his age, religion or qualification to teach. I visited the School on the morning of the 15th inst., at 9:30 a.m., there were five children present, two girls and three boys. The teacher informed me that there were ten the day before, and that it was early for the others, who would be in later.

SNULUS BAY SCHOOL

This school was reopened after the influenza epidemic had subsided in February last with Rev. Geo. Davies, in charge, and who was later succeeded by Mr. A.E. Pyall, who is still in charge with an average of about seven children in attendance. Sir,

With further reference to Department letter under date of October 24th, 1923, file 154-33-1, regarding the closing of the Shulus Indian Day School at the end of March, I beg to state that I visited the above mentioned school on the 29th ultimo, and am pleased to report that there has been a material increase in the daily attendance since the 25th of October last, on which date I attended a meeting of the Band on the Shulus Reserve. At that time I advised the Indians of the Department's decision to close the school at the end of the following March unless the daily attendance materially increased.

I am advised by Mr. Fyall that the daily attendance has increased from an average of five in 1923, to sixteen at the present time. In view of the fact that there are only about 21 children of school age on the Shulus Reserve, the increased attendance is a marked improvement. I would therefore suggest that the Department keep the school open until the 30th of June, on which date it could be closed until the First of October, as during the months of July, August and September, most of the Indians of this Reserve are away from home.

Your obedient servant,

After our conversation of the other day, I must say that it came as a considerable surprise and shock to me to see your attitude in the matter.

As you say, Mr. Fyall is in receipt of a salary of $600.00 per annum, which you will admit is far from a living wage for a man by himself, never mind a married man. The bonus you speak of, of $150.00 a year is a mere bagatelle and is not permanent by any means, so that the total of $750.00 per annum is far from being a reasonable remuneration for services rendered as ordinary every day laboring men earn far more than this.

In the second paragraph of your letter you state that Mr. Fyall is in receipt of a salary of $62.50 per month for twelve months in the year. In the fourth paragraph of your letter you state that if the bonus is cut off on March 31st., that he would then recommend that he receive a salary of $75.00 a month for his work. These two paragraphs appear to me to be somewhat conflicting, as surely if Mr. Fyall's work in March next, after eight or nine years' service is worth $75.00, it must surely be worth that much at the present time and since the First of April of the present year as stated in my recommendation.

I am forwarding a copy of this letter to Dr. Scott in order that he may see the attitude that I adopt, and I still maintain that Mr. Fyall is entitled to the increase in his salary, bonus or no bonus.

Sir,

I have to report that on Tuesday, the 8th of December, in company with Mr. R.H. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools, and Mr. A.M. Barber, attached to this office, I visited the Shuswap Indian Day School, and Mr. Cairns made his annual inspection. After the inspection was completed Mr. Cairns expressed himself very favourably with the progress of the pupils, and also the conduct of the school by Mr. A.E. Fyall, the teacher.

During our visit the matter was brought out, that Mrs. A.E. Fyall is doing an enormous amount of work among the Indian children, particularly the girls, in teaching them sewing, knitting, etc., and to my knowledge she is also doing quite a lot of missionary work among the Indians at Shuswap village, who are sick, aged or destitute. She has, to my personal knowledge, on several occasions supplied blankets, soup, jellies, etc., as well as warm clothing to several of the Indians coming under this category. For all of this Mrs. Fyall receives nothing. I took the matter up with Mr. Cairns, and Mr. Barber's presence, and we discussed the thing over fully, and Mr. Cairns was very strongly in favour of my recommending the Department that, if at all possible, in view of the good work which is being carried on gratuitously by Mrs. Fyall, she be granted a small monthly remuneration of, say, $15.00 monthly. This work has been going on for a considerable time without any compensation, and should the Department decide afloat my recommendation, I do not hesitate to state that the work will continue to go on, as Mrs. Fyall is that type of woman who would not see any of the Indians suffer for want of clothing or medical attention, and is too interested in the children to discontinue teaching them sewing and knitting just because she is not receiving any remuneration for her services.

Mrs. Fyall is a woman whose services are invaluable to the Department among a band of Indians such as the Shuswap, who are in a very low financial circumstances generally, and she is very popular among them, and is looked upon with a great deal of respect and kindness by the people of that village.

I am positive that if the Department should approach Mr. Cairns, he will strongly recommend and support these statements of mine, in fact he gave me to understand very forcibly, that he would do so, and I most respectfully submit that favourable consideration be given the matter of granting some monthly compensation to Mrs. Fyall for her time and expense in doing these works of charity and kindness for which she is, I understand, well known.

Mr. Fyall, on the other hand, I might state, is a man who has the interests of the Indians at heart and devotes a great deal of his time outside of his regular school duties to the welfare of his charges and their parents.

Respectfully submitted,

Yours obediently,

(H.F. Helmsing)
Indian Agent.

Sir:

In reference to Mr. A.E. Fyall, teacher at Shulus Indian Day School, of this Agency, I would be pleased if the Department would kindly advise us as to his status as an employee of the Department.

Mr. Fyall has been teaching at this School since 1916 continuously, being in receipt of a salary of $600.00 per annum during the period 1920-1924, 8 years. From October 1924 to December, he received an annual salary of $650.00, and since Jan. 1926 he has received $900.00 per annum, he being now in his sixteenth year of service with the Department, and he recently informed me that he did not know what his status with the Department is. Whether he is classed as a permanent employee, or Civil Servant, or only as a temporary. He has not contributed any part of his salary to the superannuation Fund, and it is in this regard that Mr. Fyall has consulted me.

I would, therefore, appreciate it, if the Department would advise as to the status of Mr. Fyall, and if he is entitled, or was entitled, to become a contributor to the Superannuation Fund under the Act. Not unnaturally, Mr. Fyall, being a married man, and hoping to spend many more years in the service of the Department and the Indians, is beginning to think of the future.

Mr. Fyall, I would respectfully advise, is very greatly interested in his work with the Indian children, and both he and Mrs. Fyall spend most of their time, irrespective of school hours, working among and with the children, and are greatly respected by all the Indians of the Lower Nicola. Sir:

In reference to Shulus Indian Day School of this Agency, which has been closed since the 16th day of October, when the teacher, Mr. A.E. Ryall, suddenly and unexpectedly tendered his resignation to the Department through Inspector Fragnell, Kamloops B.C., I now respectfully submit the following report:

I was away from the Agency from the 3rd of October to the 30th, attending the trial of the George Brothers at Vancouver. Therefore, I was unaware of the closing of the school until I received the telegram from the Department dated October 25th, which was forwarded from my office.

On the 26th Mr. Ryall called on me at my hotel in Vancouver and advised me of his resignation and told me of his troubles, which were of a personal nature, and handed over to me the keys of the School.

On the 31st October I interviewed Bishop Wells of Cariboo, at Kamloops, in regard to the school, and at my suggestion he agreed not to make any recommendation in regard to appointment of a new teacher until I had given Mr. Ryall an opportunity to return and take up his duties, which I did. However, Mr. Ryall states he is not fit to resume his duties for several months, but hopes to return after some months rest.

I have since taken up the matter again with Bishop Wells, and in consequence now forward the application of Mr. Frederick Job, Vernon B.C., for the position of Teacher at Shulus Indian Day School, together with the letters of recommendation on his behalf from both Bishop Wells of Cariboo and Bishop Adams of Kootenay.

Mr. Job's qualifications will be noted in his letter. Also it will be noted that Bishop Wells states he has seen his credentials and recommendations, and is of the opinion he will make a good teacher for the School.

I have not seen Mr. Job, whose address is Vernon B.C., but have written to him advising that his application is being forwarded to the Department for consideration, and that he will hear further in due course.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF MR. INSPECTOR BARRY, REGARDING HIS REPORT ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE SHULUS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL ON FEBRUARY 25th, 1936.

While the officials or the Department of Indian Affairs in Ottawa know my views on the employment of untrained teachers in Indian schools on the recommendation of Anglican Bishops, I wish them to know that I have done everything in my power to make Mr. Westaway's work a success. Dozens of suggestions have been noted by him during this inspection. He seems a very nice young man, and knows that he is only appointed for the balance of the term.

I wish to suggest to the Department that in this particular case, AND IF MR. WESTAWAY GOES TO THE VICTORIA SUMMER SCHOOL IN JULY, he be given a chance at Shulus for the school year 1936-37. If his work is not a success when I next inspect the school in the early part of 1937, I shall at once recommend that a new teacher be appointed for the 1937-38 school year. This will provide a reasonable check on the work done at this school and protect the interests of the Indian children. It will also probably satisfy the Right Reverend the Bishop of the Cariboo. I hope that the Department of Indian Affairs will agree with me in this, and I would ask that this letter be kept as a confidential document.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT.

Mr. Westaway is a theological student with one year's standing at the Anglican Theological College in Vancouver. This college is attached to the University of B.C. Mr. Westaway passed the Senior Matriculation Examination in Kamloops where he attended high school.

He has no qualifications whatever as a teacher. I have advised him to attend the next Provincial Summer School for Teachers to be held in Victoria and to take a course in Primary Work and a second course depending on which subjects are on the Programme of the School. I have explained to him that the Department may not sanction the continuation of his appointment here after the end of the present school year even if he does take a Summer School Course, as even then he would not have a Teachers Certificate. I have explained to him that it is unlikely that I shall be giving a course at the Summer School myself, but that if he asks me later when the Programmes are published, I shall do my best to indicate a course suitable as his Minor Subject, the work in Primary Subjects being his Major Course.

Mr. Westaway was anxious to take any hints given during my inspection. I had him write full notes of all suggestions so that he would not forget them later. I look on him as a boy who has probably been a good student with no particular intention of taking up teaching as a profession. He obviously wishes to get as much money as will take him through the remainder of his Theological Course, a further two years. The greater part of the time during this inspection was devoted to the instruction of this young man, programmes of work to be covered in the various Grades and Sub Grades being indicated, and a number of short lessons taught. Methods in teaching some of the most important Primary and Junior work were indicated on the blackboard. In fact I believed that the Department would wish me to do my best in the very limited time to give Mr. Westaway some idea of what he should do in the schoolroom, and in this belief I did all that possibly could for this young man.

While this young man knows nothing about teaching from a professional point of view, his attitude is good, he appears to be liked by the people, and if he will go to the Provincial Summer School in Victoria this next July, might be quite a success here. In any case I have done the best I can for him at the moment.
The Secretary,

Many colds and coughs on the reserves and an epidemic of measles at Shulus Indian Reserve, necessitating the closing of the Day School. I enclose herewith a copy of a report received from Miss V.V. Mosher on her work with adult Indians at the Shulus Indian Reserve. Miss Mosher has just completed her first very successful year as our teacher at Shulus.

The organization of night classes for adult Indians was undertaken by Miss Mosher shortly after her appointment and I am sure you will be interested in this brief account of her efforts in this direction.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Enc.
In August of 1944 I was commissioned to teach at the Shulus Indian Day School. This school had not been operated for two years hence it was necessary to gather the children together preparatory to the re-opening of the school.

This necessitated my visiting all the homes on the Reserve and brought me in contact with the parents and young people. After the school became a going concern and I had spent much time in visiting the parents to gain their cooperation, I felt there was a need for something in the educational life for the older people, even if it was only to encourage cleanliness and a right way of living.

After chatting with them and becoming friendly which took some time to accomplish - at first they would shut their door and talk to me outside, now it is "Come in, Come in" - they volunteered that they would like to meet together to learn to improve themselves.

On November 29, 1944, the first meeting was held with about 20 present, a mixed company of adults. From then on for two evenings a week, Tuesday and Fridays, (7:30 p.m. to 10:00 p.m.) a study was made of Reading, Writing, English, Arithmetic, Geography and Singing. The adults were placed in two classes, Beginners and Advanced Beginners. Some of them could not read at all, but were all very interested in learning, and during the year have made fairly good progress. A few adults could write quite nicely, others had to start from zero. As spelling improved it was found easier to write, and spelling was made as pleasant as possible by its connection with stories. Some elementary lessons in Grammar were taught to improve their use of the English language in order to eradicate some of their peculiarities of speech. The men often brought their problems to night school, as how to measure hay on the stack by the ton. This for instance brought in a review of their neglected arithmetic. In Geography they were interested in deep sea and inshore fishing as compared with their own efforts on the lakes and rivers. A special study was made of all the provinces in Canada with their different resources. During the course of each evening a period was set aside for singing. At first they were very bashful but the more acquainted they became the greater was the volume of sound, and to my joy I found that the sound was "real harmony" giving me the idea of a future "Toy" Symphony Orchestra.
Finding that Sundays were spent by the Indians very often in not to be desired occupations, I gave Sunday evening classes which consisted of Bible Study and Singing. The Indians seemed to appreciate this very much, often bringing their children.

One product of these evenings was a sacred concert on Good Friday of this year when the white people and Indians gathered together in the hall and the Indians gave such a creditable performance that the white people were astonished beyond measure.

For the purpose of teaching singing it was necessary to have a reasonably decent piano, I was fortunate to be able to rent from "Lower Nicola Community." When about sixteen Indians brought a truck to return it on June 20, 1945, they asked for music before taking it away, and at the end insisted on singing, "God be with you till we meet again." It was a sad moment when the piano disappeared from sight; wondering what would happen with regard to the future and whether I or some one else would be able to continue along the lines we had started and develop a higher culture among the Indians.

With regard to their social life, they overcame their shyness and as their English improved they entered into conversation quite easily. At first their manners were not particularly polite but there is a marked difference in this side of their character.

Cleanliness, as learned through the children and night school has made vast strides, both in person and in their homes. The adults know I am going to visit them and they know that I am prepared to eat with them on occasion when they so invite me therefore they put forth their best efforts to have everything as nice as possible. I find that "visiting them" is an education in itself and will eventually draw goodly numbers to the night school (provided that I return in the fall to carry on with the work).

There was an average attendance at night school of 22, with about 33 names on the roll.

I did find the Indians very appreciative of all that I have done for their welfare, the climax coming when they gave me a "Farewell Party" presenting me with a gift accompanying it. I received various small personal gifts and the cry was "Please come back," "Please come back with us."
No words could express how much I have enjoyed the work among the Indians during the past year. At times it has been strenuous and hard but there has been a great joy in "much serving."

If circumstances over which I have no control prevent my return to Shulus I hope that someone else will be prepared to give their time and talents to carry on this work I have so much enjoyed and not find the extra burden too great.

All of which is respectfully submitted,

"V. Verlean Mosher"

For D. M. MacKay,

Report on Adult Education of the men and women on Shulus Indian Reserve.

Night classes were continued this year with much success. From Nov. 22 1945 - Easter 1946 three classes were held each week, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sunday Evenings, with an attendance of 20 adults and 10 children. We continued with Arith. Geo. Hist. English, Singing, etc.

At Christmas we had a concert of sacred and comic numbers by children and adults. Thursday in Holy Week we had a sacred concert by the children. At both the children played the Rhythm Band instruments which we started this year. At our Christmas concert we raised enough money to buy the set of instruments for our school. I continued my visits among the Indians helping them in times of sickness, sorrow, etc. I feel that through my visits at their homes as well as through our classes, there is a big improvement in their appearance, health and manners.

I am more convinced than ever that a teacher through the Indian Day Schools can be a great help in developing a higher culture among the Indians.

The Indians have been very grateful to me for all I did for their welfare. My sincere wish is that the work I have so well started and enjoyed will be continued with much success.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

"V. Verlean Mosher"
(Teacher of Shulus Indian Day School. Sept. 1944 - June 1946)

Dear Miss Sawyer:

I have just answered your letter of October 7 which arrived when I was absent from Ottawa on a school inspection trip to the Province of Manitoba. I regret that you have not apparently become thoroughly acquainted with the difference between employment as a "temporary civil servant" and as a "permanent civil servant", as outlined in various issues of the Indian School Bulletin.

As an Indian day school teacher, you were classified as a temporary civil servant until such time as your application for appointment as a permanent civil servant was approved in the prescribed way. The details of this procedure were outlined in issues of the Indian School Bulletin. You did not, apparently, make application for classification as a permanent civil servant.

I also note that, had you done so, you would not have been eligible because of the fact that you do not hold a teacher's certificate granted by one of our provincial Departments of Education. While we are allowed to give credit for an English teacher's certificate for the purposes of our salary schedule, our regulations specifically require the holding of a provincial teacher's certificate before the classification of Permanent Civil Servant can be requested. These points were made very clear in the June 1947 issue of the Indian School Bulletin, as follows:

"The classification of permanent civil servant for the purposes of superannuation will be applied only to certain of our teachers as detailed below:

(a) Teachers who are in possession of permanent teaching certificates as granted by Provincial Departments of Education."
(b) Teachers who have been employed for a period of at least two years as Indian Day School Teachers and upon whose work satisfactory School Inspectors' and Indian Agents' reports have been submitted.

(c) Teachers who otherwise qualify within the regulations laid down in the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

(d) Teachers of day schools in operation for a full academic year of ten months.

Note: Married women to be eligible must provide proof of the fact that they are, of necessity, self-supporting."

The Retirement Fund was set up for temporary civil servants and since September 1, 1939, a deduction has been made from the salary of all such civil servants. This subject was clarified in the December 1946 issue of the Bulletin, as follows:

"Teachers in Indian Day Schools are at present classified as temporary Civil Servants. Like all temporary civil servants a deduction, therefore, is made from the salaries of those who have joined the service since 1 September, 1939. This deduction is at the rate of 5% and is called a Retirement Fund withdrawal. Please note that this deduction is not made from the salaries of teachers who were in the service prior to 1 September, 1939.

When teachers leave the Service the total amount of these withdrawals is returned to them with interest at the rate of 4%."

You will note that I stated in the beginning of my letter that I had recently inspected schools in Manitoba. As a result of my visit, we are opening three temporary classrooms as additions to present day schools. I found a serious shortage of teachers in Manitoba and since I have returned to Ottawa, I understand that we may be able to get special authority...
to hire teachers approaching or past the age of 65, for teaching services in that province.

These positions are at the Poguie Centre and North Bay Schools, near Redfern, Manitoba, and at the Fairfield No. 3 Indian Day School, near Cypressville, Manitoba. I note from one of your previous letters that you are anxious to return to England. If you are interested in one of these positions, I would like to hear from you as soon as possible. Your salary would be at the rate of $156.00 a teaching month, plus free house and fuel (to be shared with another teacher).

REGULATIONS GOVERNING THE EMPLOYMENT OF TEACHERS IN INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS

1. An Indian day school teacher may be notified of his (or her) appointment or dismissal by official letter or by an Indian Agent acting under instructions from Head Office.

2. An Indian day school teacher is not required to sign a formal contract and may be dismissed for cause at any time. It is the policy of the Department, however, to give a month's notice prior to dismissal and it is expected that a teacher desiring to resign shall notify the Department at least one month prior to the date on which the resignation is to become effective.

3. Teachers of Indian day schools are temporary government employees and do not come under the Civil Service Act. They do not contribute to the government superannuation fund and do not qualify for superannuation allowances.

4. Teachers of Indian day schools must hold the complete academic and professional certificates required by the Province in which the Indian school is located.

5. Salaries are paid monthly. The teacher is required at the end of September, December, March and June to prepare a quarterly return and to send this promptly to the Indian Agent. The illness of a teacher, or the closing of a school, for any cause, should be immediately reported to the Agent.

6. Teachers in Indian day schools are required to be protected by successful vaccination against Smallpox, and by the toxoid treatment against Diphtheria, and evidence of such protection, in the form of a certificate from a qualified physician, should, if possible, be included with the application for employment.

7. Teachers should send all requisitions for school supplies to the local Indian Agent. They should notify the Agent when repairs to school buildings are required. Strict observance of this regulation will obviate unnecessary delay and ensure prompt action when duly authorized requests for supplies reach the Department.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Qualicum Beach, B. C.

Dear Mr. Arneil:

Reference your 1-11-3 of April 9, 1948,

O-11-3 " 15, 1948.

You will recall the letter forwarded to you recently with regard to co-operation with provincial Departments of Education insofar as it concerned the future educational plans for Indian children.

A study of Inspector Davey's reports and the late Inspector Coleman's survey (February 25, 1947) indicates clearly that Hazelton is one of the places at which we could cooperate with local educational authorities. It would seem obvious that, if arrangements can be made for these Indian children to attend the new white school, this arrangement would certainly be better than constructing our own Indian school just across the road from their new school. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you could discuss this matter with Inspector Davey and have him visit educational officials in Victoria to ascertain if they are interested in such a proposal. The Parliamentary Committee feels that we should be generous in making these agreements and there is a possibility that we might even be able to get authority for a partial payment of capital cost. This latter point is a difficult thing to discuss with provincial authorities as we are not sure whether we have the necessary constitutional authority under the old Indian Act. However, Inspector Davey could discuss with provincial educational officials:

(a) their reaction to the operation of such a school,
(b) their ideas as to how the school could best be financed.

Mr. J. L. Gibson, M.P., has contacted our Division with regard to claims made by Miss Sawyer concerning the payment of back salary. It would seem that the only claim which she now has on the Department is with regard to the wording of the dismissal notice sent her. Her claim is of course that she interprets your letter to mean that her dismissal was to be effective at the end of June, 1949. If you will review this letter yourself, you can understand how it
is possible to take such a meaning out of it, particularly when money is concerned.

It may be necessary therefore to make a payment to Miss Sawyer of one month's extra salary, in lieu of the month's dismissal notice required by our regulations. I would suggest that in future every care be taken to ensure that dismissal notices are very clear and that no ambiguity exists. Mr. Gibson is again writing to Miss Sawyer and we will hear from him further when he has had a reply.

Feb 9th 1949

Dear Mr. Gibson,

I wish to thank you for your letter of 5th inst.

There is no doubt in my mind that I was prematurely released from the service without adequate notice. This sudden severance not only embarrassed me financially but also cast a slur upon my professional reputation. The latter was removed by the offer of re-employment, and your letter suggesting one month's salary in lieu of notice is some acknowledgment of the monetary loss I sustained.

I should like to assure you that in pressing my claim as I have done, I have been motivated solely by a sense of justice and fair play both for my professional colleagues and myself and not in any spirit of vindictiveness or mere desire for financial recompense, although I am by no means a 'well-to-do' person.

In view of the foregoing I am prepared to accept the suggestion you have made, one month's salary, $156.00, in lieu of notice in full settlement of my claim against the Department.

I am deeply indebted to you for your interest and help. I felt any appeal to you could not fail to receive sympathetic consideration and prompt action.

Yours gratefully,

St. Dorothy Sawyer.

General Comment:

It is a pleasure to visit this class-room. The children have made excellent progress in the basic subjects of reading, number work and language and have developed good work habits and attitudes. They quite obviously enjoy their work in school.

It will be noted that the school enrolment has reached 32 and I believe an effort should be made to secure the admission of Grades 4 and above to the Provincial school. I have already asked the Superintendent to investigate this possibility. This proposal would leave an adequate pupilage for a primary school and would avoid the construction of an additional room in the near future, as well as give the advantage of joint education. Since the pupils would have to be transported on the Provincial school bus some 4 or more miles, I do not believe we should seek the admission to the Provincial school of the three primary grades.

Memorandum,

Re new school building.

Department in letter to Senator H. Bostock, dated February 11th, states definitely—"I propose to include in the Supplementary estimates for consideration of the Superintendent General an item for $3000.00 for the erection of school building".

Extract from Inspector's report:—

"An old Indian building 20 by 30 feet is loaned for school purposes. The benches are borrowed from the church and are carried backwards and forwards weekly. A new school house is urgently required. Desks are needed and could be made nearby."

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6412, file 842-5, part 1)
Ottawa, April 8th, 1910.

Very Reverend Sir,

In the month of January, last, the Department received through Senator Bostock a communication from you in which, among other things, application was made for a grant to erect a school and a hospital at Shulus.

Senator Bostock has no doubt communicated to you the reply of the Department, which was to the effect that a salary of $600.00 would be allowed a physician, this to include cost of medicines, and that assistance would be given to establish a day school.

I may say that the Department quite agrees with you as to the benefits to be derived from day schools on the reserves under competent teachers and to enable you to carry out the programme you have in view Parliament has been asked to appropriate the sum of $3000.00 to erect a modern school-house at Shulus.

Anticipating that this sum will be voted the Department would like to have from you a report in which you should deal with the size of building necessary, the material of which it should be composed, the best means in your opinion of having the work performed, whether by day labour or by contract, and whether a suitable site on the reserve

Ven. Archdeacon Edward W.W. Pugh,
The Mission House,
Lytton, B.C.
2.

is available, one easily drained and of sufficient area to allow gardening operations to be conducted, if the soil is suitable.

Any additional information or suggestions you can give the Department will be gladly received.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.
Ottawa, May 11, 1910.

Very Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th ultimo in further reference to the erection of a school and a hospital at Shulus, B.C.

In reply I beg to say that, as the attitude of the Department in the matter of assistance towards these projects is apparently not clearly understood, it would appear expedient to recall previous correspondence.

In your letter to Senator Bostock of January 20, last, after dealing with the necessity for two new buildings you wrote as follows:

"These buildings will cost in all between furniture, land, pump-house, etc., over $7000.00. I shall be glad if you will kindly go into it and if you can support my application will you help us in getting a grant from the Department towards the buildings. If we can get $3000.00 towards the hospital and school it will make it possible for us to get about it this year."

Senator Bostock was told that the Department was disposed to grant the assistance asked for and that the sum of $3000.00 would be inserted in the Supplementary Estimates for consideration, but that it was thought best to confine whatever aid was to be given to the school.

In official letter of the 6th ultimo you were

Ven. Archdeacon Edward W. W. Bush,
The Mission House,
Lytton, B.C.
advised that Parliament had been asked to appropriate $3000.00 to erect a school-house and the Department, anticipating the vote, asked for certain information as to the proposed building. This grant was made and the sum of $3000.00 is now available to proceed with the erection of the school building.

In view of the fact that the Department has complied with your original request and provided the required amount ($3000.00) your application in letter of the 14th ultimo for a grant towards an hospital building, so that both buildings might be erected at the same time, is not understood. True the Department confined its aid to the school building, but made such provision that the church will not be called on for any part of the cost and will thus be in a position to devote its available funds to the hospital. The Department was asked for aid and responded to the extent asked.

You will be good enough, therefore, to send a sketch of a building you think would be suitable for school purposes, stating the number of pupils to be accommodated and an approximate estimate of the cost. You might also say whether there are contractors in the neighborhood who would be competent and willing to undertake the work. No doubt better prices could be had if both buildings were erected at the same time.

With reference to the salaries I beg to say that in the letter to Senator Bostock it was stated that the Department would pay the current rate for teachers' salaries in British Columbia. The amount to be paid will depend upon the qualifications and the work done. If field matron work is undertaken the services of those engaged will
be paid for, but until the nature and extent of this work is known a limit in salary cannot well be set.

Your remarks in regard to the salary for a doctor will be dealt with in another communication.

Trusting to hear from you again at an early date,

I am,

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.
The Mission House
Lytton, B.C.

April 14th, 1910

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of yours of last
31st ult., No 336204/1 and also of April 7th No 336204/5
I have been away from home I had no opportunity of answering letter, I sincerely hope my delay will not inconvenience you.

With regard to your first letter, Capt. B.L. Willey is a present taking temporary charge at Shuswap, he is really an excellent teacher I was educated at Charterhouse & Sandhurst & is a good disciplinarian.

Capt. Willey is only helping out until we get proper help from home, I have reported things to our house committee and asked them to send out a university graduate either with his wife and another lady or else a graduate with two sisters so that the school work can be followed up with proper visiting on the reserve & that the ladies teach the older Indians how to cook, care for their children & keep their houses clean. Simply the school itself is not sufficient, and a male teacher must have ladies with him to do the work well to look after the while ladies alone although they can teach sewing, cooking, embroidery & house cleaning can never...
influence the children to attend regularly as a man can through the parents; Smeaton Bostock in his letter says the Department is willing to pay the ordinary rate of teacher's salary, if we have a fully qualified teacher - in this country the lowest rate of teacher's salary is $55.00 per month - but judging from Smeaton Bostock's letter I also believe I should think they did not anticipate more than $600.00 per year to this own funds at home have promised $960.00 per year so that I hope to be able to hire three teachers on the Reserve and to aim at doing all we can for the welfare of the Indians in every way, teaching them about farming, gardening and stock-raising.

We hope to put up buildings near the Reserve touching the road on a piece of land suggested & the Chief as there is splendid drainage and it is a particularly healthy site.
