Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of yours of June 31st ult., No. 336204/1 and also of April 2nd No. 336204/5. I have been away from home and had no opportunity of answering either, I sincerely hope my delay will not inconvenience you.

With regard to your first letter, Capt. B. L. Hillyer is a present taking temporary charge at Shuswap, he is really an excellent teacher & was educated at Charterhouse & Sandhurst & is a good disciplinarian.

Capt. Hillyer is only helping out until we get proper help from home, I have represented things to our Home Committee and asked them to send out a University graduate either with his wife and another lady or else a graduate with two sisters so that the School work can be followed up with proper visiting on the Reserve & that the ladies teach the older Indians how to cook, care for their children & keep their houses clean. Simply the School itself is not sufficient, and a male teacher must have ladies with him to do the work with to help advantage while ladies alone although they can teach sewing, cooking, embroidery & house cleaning can never...
influence the children to attend regularly as a man can through the parents; Sinclair Bostock in his letter says the Department is willing to pay the ordinary rate of teacher's salary, if we have a fully qualified teacher—in this country the lowest rate of teacher's salary is $55.00 per month—but judging from Sinclair Bostock's letter I also in Ridley's I almost think they do not anticipate more than $600.00 per year to His own funds at home have promised $960.00 per year so that I hope to be able to have three teachers on the Reserve and to arise at once all in case for the well being of the Indians in every way, teaching them about farming, gardening and stock-raising.

We hope to put up buildings near the Reserve, structuring the road on a piece of land suggested by Mr. Chief as there is splendid drainage and it is a particularly healthy site. I have not had any plans drawn out yet as I do not know how much money we shall have until you grant has been made, for the School building there else I would like one big and two smaller Class-rooms with porch and lavatory outside, and the teachers' house attached and the necessary closets and outbuildings, a deep well must be deep and an engine put in to pump the necessary water for School-house—and Hospital—if in course—The Hospital immediately here we shall have to do so as soon as possible.
At Sutton we have a resident medical officer, & I also studied medicine at Cambridge, but he does not work for any grant for the present from the Department. He has been here for two months or so before him we had Dr. Scott but he went home to take up new appointment offered to him there; our present medical officer was also in the staff of one of the London Hospitals and intends returning here in the autumn and will get a young man to come out & they will both settle down here, so that if this is away the other will be at hand; such is the present situation.

Between the House & Mission Fund $960.00 is provided for the salary of the Resident Medical Officer independent by of any Government Grant.

With regard to Shielus what I distinctly feel is it would be a tremendous advantage if the Government could give us a grant towards the building of a Hospital now so that both buildings could be put up at one time, they must be same buildings, plastered or cemented, with furnaces & put up by contract, the greater part of the labour will have to come from the Vancouver Mills and it will save a saving tons in cost of freight & travelling expenses where the whole lot done at once.

These plans have Mr. Youell's entire support and approval.

I. D. Maclean, Sec'y

Very Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th ultimo in further reference to the erection of a school and a hospital at Shulus, B.C.

In reply I beg to say that, as the attitude of the Department in the matter of assistance towards these projects is apparently not clearly understood, it would appear expedient to recall previous correspondence.

In your letter to Senator Bostock of January 20, last, after dealing with the necessity for two new buildings you wrote as follows:

"These buildings will cost in all between furniture, land, pump-house, etc., over $7000.00. I shall be glad if you will kindly go into it and if you can support my application will you help us in getting a grant from the Department towards the buildings. If we can get $3000.00 towards the hospital and school it will make it possible for us to set about it this year."

Senator Bostock was told that the Department was disposed to grant the assistance asked for and that the sum of $3000.00 would be inserted in the supplementary estimates for consideration, but that it was thought best to confine whatever aid was to be given to the school.

In official letter of the 8th ultimo you were

Ven. Archdeacon Edward W. W. Pugh,
The Mission House,
Lytton, B.C.
advised that Parliament had been asked to appropriate $3000.00 to erect a school-house and the Department, anticipating the vote, asked for certain information as to the proposed building. This grant was made and the sum of $3000.00 is now available to proceed with the erection of the school building.

In view of the fact that the Department has complied with your original request and provided the required amount ($3000.00) your application in letter of the 14th ultimo for a grant towards an hospital building, so that both buildings might be erected at the same time, is not understood. True the Department confined its aid to the school building, but made such provision that the church will not be called on for any part of the cost and will thus be in a position to devote its available funds to the hospital. The Department was asked for aid and responded to the extent asked.

You will be good enough, therefore, to send a sketch of a building you think would be suitable for school purposes, stating the number of pupils to be accommodated and an approximate estimate of the cost. You might also say whether there are contractors in the neighborhood who would be competent and willing to undertake the work. No doubt better prices could be had if both buildings were erected at the same time.

With reference to the salaries I beg to say that in the letter to Senator Bostock it was stated that the Department would pay the current rate for teachers' salaries in British Columbia. The amount to be paid will depend upon the qualifications and the work done. If field matron work is undertaken the services of those engaged will
be paid for, but until the nature and extent of this work is known a limit in salary cannot well be set.

Your remarks in regard to the salary for a doctor will be dealt with in another communication.

Trusting to hear from you again at an early date,

I am,

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

Dear Sir,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant in reference to the site of the proposed Shuswap school-house.

In reply I beg to say that the Department can erect a building only on reserve land. Under existing conditions the suggestion to obtain a surrender of a portion of the reserve cannot be given consideration. The Department can, however, with the consent of the Indians give the owner right of occupancy so long as the proposed hospital and other buildings are used for the purposes of Indian education and the land remains an Indian reserve.

Dear Sir,

We have again to consider the land I referred to in my former letter, which I observe is situated between Mr. James Agnew's homestead but the owner positively declines to sell any part unless we buy the whole of his quarter section. Once again we quite decide that the School Reserve is at present an utterly impossible location for any building as it is flooded during the irrigation season or the great cut of drainage to place it quite outside any but those who are prepared to spend several thousand dollars in sewage pipeline alone. So we have decided to build on the Reserve on land adjoining the Smith pre-emption & the rail road, it is near a good spring of water, dry gravelly soil, free from hoppers and mosquitoes & is to all our minds quite the best piece anywhere on the Reserve & closer to the Indians themselves as being the most suitable.

Very Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of the 27th ultimo enclosing ground floor plans of a hospital, dwelling house and school building which it is proposed to erect for the Indians on the Sholus reserve.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased to learn that you have decided to erect these buildings upon reserve property and it would be prepared upon completion of the work to give the amount of the grant promised, viz.-$3000.00, it to be understood that the school building is to be solely the property of the Department.

Certain modifications, however, in the plan of the school building are considered advisable. In the first place the height of the wall is given as only ten feet. The larger of the two class-rooms provides floor space for 24 pupils, but, if only ten feet in height, the cubic air space would only be sufficient for 16 pupils. The floor space of the smaller room has accommodation for 21 children, but the air space will only accommodate 13. You will see from this that it is absolutely necessary that the ceilings be higher to provide adequate air space for the number of children in each room for whom there is floor space. The ceiling should be at least 15 feet high. This, however, will not add very much to the cost of the building.

The wisdom of having two small class-rooms in a building

Ven. Archdeacon Edward W. W. Pugh,
The Mission House,
Lutton, B.C.
building of this size is not apparent, in fact one teacher would have no difficulty in teaching the number of pupils for which space would be provided even with the ceilings 15 feet high, as suggested. Two class-rooms will necessitate two teachers. The Department will, of course, be pleased to provide two teachers should the attendance of Indian children at the school warrant such action. It is suggested that there should be only one class-room of the size at present occupied by the two rooms, or, if it is considered advisable to provide two class-rooms, that the space be increased by adding a few feet to the width of the building and to the length of the class-room by reducing the width of the teacher's room and waiting room. I would ask you, therefore, to re-consider the plan of the school-room, which can no doubt be done to the mutual satisfaction of yourself and the Department.

I would also add that it would save delay if these matters were brought to the attention of the Department through the office of the local Indian Agent. In the meantime could not the contractor proceed with the erection of the residence and hospital buildings? Adequate provision should be made in the class-room and hospital buildings for a system of artificial ventilation.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Before the balance of the grant can be paid, it is necessary that the Department receive a voucher covering the same. The Department should be furnished with receipted accounts from all persons who supplied material for the erection of the building, or who were paid for labour. In company with the Agent, I visited the Day School at Shulus Reserve, which has been in charge of Mr. Fyall for so many years. The school was neat and tidy and everything in good order. There were present sixteen children out of a roll of 17. The children were divided into Grades 1, 2, and 4, besides beginners.

Both Grades 1 and 2 read well and grade 2 seems a little ahead of their work. Grade 4 also read well. This grade was good at mathematics, and the lower grades up to their work. The children seemed bright and intelligent and not too shy, but anxious to show what they could do. Discipline was excellent and Mr. Fyall knows how to handle and interest the children.

I am very pleased with the school throughout, and I know that both Mr. and Mrs. Fyall are, in an unobtrusive way doing excellent work in other ways on the Reserve, not only amongst the children but parents as well. Mr. Fyall gives the children a certain amount of manual training and his wife teaches them sewing and mending besides health hygiene.

Indian Agent Barber expressed every satisfaction with Mr. Fyall's work in every way.

I understand that Mr. Fyall has now been with the Department for eighteen years, but is not on the Superannuation list. I understood that this was now obligatory.

Yours truly,

With reference to his inspection of the Shulus Day School, on the 25th ultimo, Inspector Barry states as follows:

"The desks should be placed on strips of wood. At present they tilt all over the place and make control of the pupils just that much harder. EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR BARRY,
DATED FEBRUARY 25, 1936, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE
SHULUS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

The desks should be placed on strips of wood.
At present they tilt all over the place, and make control
of the pupils just that much harder. If more pupils come
to school as seems likely owing to the popularity of the
teacher the desks might be placed at right angles to
their present position so that the children will have
light from over their left shoulders. If the desks
are placed on strips in the way indicated to the teacher
there will be enough seating for about 24 children. By
the present arrangement in short rows several available
desks are not made full use of owing to the absence of
rear sections. The teacher is doing his best. His
control is fair at present. I have shown the teacher
how the room might be cleared of useless articles, and
the school in general made more tidy outside.

Many of the children come a mile or more I am in-
formed. They buying bread for their lunch. They are
drinking tea without milk or sugar at the school. I
should like to think that the Department would consider
this problem and if possible make a small grant of say
$2 per month throughout the year, so that the teacher
might provide COCOA, MILK & SUGAR for these little child-
ren. I have asked the teacher to take this matter up
with the Department through his Indian Agent.

July 5th, 1938.

Sir:

I beg to forward herewith the quarterly report of Shulus Indian Day School, together with requisition for School material, on which it will be noted a lock and key is the first item.

I have inspected the School and find that the outside door lock is broken, and the teacher is at present unable to lock the building.

I would be pleased to be authorized to have a new lock installed, at a cost of approximately $6.00. I find suitable locks are priced at $4.00 and Yale at $5.25, plus a reasonable charge for installation.

Early authorization of this in order that the building may be securely locked whilst closed for the summer, will be appreciated.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:-

Provision has been made in my estimates for the past several years, for the following:

Shulus Indian Day School.

Painting Exterior of School $90.00
Tar or Stain for Roof $45.00
Total $135.00

I would be pleased to be advised if authority could now be granted to have this work carried out.

The roof of the School was re-shingled in 1936, and to ensure longer life of the shingles, the roof should be either stained or tarred at this time.

The exterior of the building is very badly in need of paint for the protection of the wood work, which is now beginning to check and crack, and I respectfully recommend that authority to expend the above sum on this work be granted.

The figures shown are based on tenders obtained for the work in 1936.

Yours obediently,

AHR/ES

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd ultimo with reference to painting the Shulus Indian Day School.

In preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year it was found possible to include an amount of $100.00 only for the above purpose. It is noted from your letter that the exterior of the school can be painted for $90.00. Consequently, funds are available for this work. If the material required does not cost over $50.00 you may proceed with the painting immediately. If, however, the material will cost over $50.00 it will be necessary for you to let me have full details regarding the paint required in order that purchase can be arranged by our Purchasing Branch.

Owing to lack of funds it will not be possible to tar or stain the roof this year.

Ottawa,
October 31, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Reporting on his inspection of the Shulus Indian day school on October 4 Inspector Barry states that as the Anglican Missionary no longer lives in the Mission House at Shulus the teacher and her elderly mother have rented this residence from the Church authorities in order to be close to the school. The Inspector further reports as follows:

"The teacher in this way is of much greater assistance to the Indian Agent as she can assist with community efforts in the Indian village. Miss Aylwin is, I understand, paying some $10.00 per month for the use of this Mission House, which she has furnished. I would request that if possible she be allowed a sum of $5.00 per teaching month towards its rent, and that she be further allowed $30.00 worth of coal for heating her home per year. Some correspondence has, I understand, been received from the Indian Agent in this matter. In the northern part of the Province fuel is provided in many schools for the use of the teacher, even when the latter is Missionary and living in a Mission House. Here the extra assistance given by the teacher due to her residence on the actual Indian reserve is in my opinion worth more than the suggested assistance towards rent and fuel. The winters are very cold indeed at Merritt and I am most anxious that Miss Aylwin be given the assistance noted above so that we may make use of her services among the women and children of the reserve, the Indians being in many ways quite backward."

Mr. G. C. Mortimer,
Indian Agent,
Merritt, B. C.
I should appreciate your advising if you consider it necessary to allow the amount recommended by the Inspector toward the rent of the house and for supplying coal.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
EXTRA CT FROM REPORT OF GERALD H. BARRY, DISTRICT INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS, BRITISH COLUMBIA.

dated October 4, 1938. - Original on 169-13-6

SHULUS DAY SCHOOL

The Anglican Missionary no longer lives in the Mission House at Shulus. The teacher and her elderly mother have rented this Mission House from the church authorities to be within a few yards of the school. The teacher in this way is of much greater assistance to the Indian Agent as she can assist with community efforts in the Indian village.

Miss Aylwin is, I understand, paying some $10.00 per month for the use of this Mission House, which she has furnished. I would request that if possible she be allowed a sum of $5.00 per teaching month towards its rent, and that she be further allowed $50.00 worth of coal for heating her home per year. Some correspondence has, I understand, been received from the Indian Agent in this matter. In the northern part of the Province fuel is provided in many schools for the use of the teacher, even when the latter is Missionary and living in a Mission House. Here the extra assistance given by the teacher due to her residence on the actual Indian reserve is in my opinion worth more than the suggested assistance towards rent and fuel. The winters are very cold indeed at Merritt and I am most anxious that Miss Aylwin be given the assistance noted above so that we may make use of her services among the women and children of the reserve, the Indians being in many ways quite backward.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF COMMISSIONER MACKAY, dated Oct. 13, 1939

With reference to the penultimate paragraph of Inspector Barry's covering letter, I would endorse the recommendation made, provided it is the policy of the Department to extend such assistance to our day school teachers and also that Miss Aylwin undertakes to visit the Indian women and children in their homes and does what she can to assist them in the ways suggested to her by the Inspector.

Dear Sir:

Many of these small children walk long distances to school and home, and a hot nourishing drink aids greatly in preventing colds, and undernourishment.

Provision is made in the estimates for this expenditure, and the Department has granted the expenditure during the past two winters.

In looking over the wood-shed at Shulus School I found the roof in very bad shape. The roofing is past fixing and will take one roll of new roofing.

An Axe is also badly needed for the wood-shed.

Rope for swings in the yard would give the children something to amuse themselves with in their play-time.

As Miss Mosher to give entertainments for the children during the winter as well as teach older girls after school hours, lamps will be needed and coal oil.

I had hoped to get soft-balls but find it impossible.

I have been trying to work out a scheme to make the building warmer by building a board form around the outside walls from the ground to just above floor level and about twelve inches away from the wall and having this filled with saw-dust or shavings. This I am sure would make the building much warmer and keep out the drafts in windy weather. If this meets with your approval I will obtain tenders for lumber and filling.

G.E. Sharpe,
Indian Agent.

Re: Aid to Christmas Fund, Shulus School.

While at the School this afternoon Miss Mosher requested me to ask if there was any hope of this Department granting any money toward providing the pupils of the Shulus School with small presents at a Christmas Tree Party to be held in the school at the Christmas season.

There were thirteen children in class today and that is about the regular number now.

She is very much put out that Mr. Ashley wont be interested as he states that the church is in no way connected with the school. (I can see quite clearly now why she lives at the school).

I would greatly appreciate any help you might see fit to get for this first Christmas of the re-opened school.

G.E. Sharpe,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, June 13, 1945.

AIR MAIL

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to purchasing a piano at a cost of $100.00 for the Shulus Indian Day School.

I have discussed this request with Mr. Hoey and we feel that it would not be advisable to purchase this piano. Our experience has been that to make effective use of such an instrument it is necessary to have a teacher who is able to play the piano, and such teachers are the exception rather than the rule. If a piano is not being used it would soon deteriorate.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Miss V.V. Mosher, teacher of the Shulus Indian Day School, has since December last been renting a piano for the school at the rate of $3.00 per month. This instrument was rented from the Lower Nicola Public School Board and as they are at present endeavouring to sell the piano the Department will no longer be able to have the use of it unless we buy it. The price asked is $100.00 and as it has been of great value at the school and Miss Mosher has given excellent service as a teacher, I would recommend that if funds are available authority be granted for the purchase of the instrument.

An early reply would be appreciated as if the Department is unable to buy the piano, it will be necessary to return it to the Lower Nicola School Board before the end of June.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Repairs to Shulus School

I have at last found a carpenter to alter the windows at Shulus School so as to allow more blackboard space.

He estimates the total cost of labour, material and paint, at $45.00.

If authority is granted the work will be done on a long weekend.

I would also request authority to supply a screen door for the school at an estimated cost of $5.00. It is a large door and needs to be made to order.

G.E. Sharpe
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Sharpe's letter of September 6th in connection with repairs to the Shulus Indian Day School building at a cost of $45.00 and the purchase of a screen door at an estimated cost of $5.00.

An amount of $50.00 is provided in the current estimates for this purpose and it is recommended that Mr. Sharpe be authorized to proceed with the work and purchase the door.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

RE:- Additions to Shulus Indian Day School,
Lower Nicola I.R. No.1.

I am forwarding a plan of the proposed construction. This has been made for me by a local building contractor, (J.Okert)

Mr. Davey expressed the desire to have the classroom enlarged if possible and several changes in its appointment such as dimensions and lighting etc.

In the enclosed plan you will note that we have moved the north wall of the present class room back approximately four feet taking that chimney out entirely.

The main entrance has been moved from the south west corner to the centre of the west side. Windows from South side moved to the East side to light from the left side of seating arrangement.

The extension to the north of 14 feet with an added extension at the North West corner will make a fine teacherage of 3 rooms and bath. The rooms marked bathrooms at both sides of the main entrance are in hopes of inside toilets when running water is put in and will do away with the present out houses, 3 in number.

If this plan is approved, Mr. Okert will submit his estimate of cost completed to your specifications and be prepared to do the work as far as time will permit this summer holidays. He is a good workman and the only carpenter in the area.

The plan shows the location of two chimneys one for the kitchen and one for the class room which will also serve for the teacherage living quarters.

I am sure that Mr. Davey, having examined the present building will readily understand the new plan.

Mr. Okert will not dismantle the roof except to extend it to cover the addition on the north.

G. H. Sharpe,
Superintendent.

June 25, 1949.

Re: Teacherage, Shulus Indian day School

I refer to Mr. Superintendent Sharpe's letter of June 22nd with the attached plan for the alterations to the above mentioned school.

In my opinion, the plan submitted by Mr. Sharpe is an excellent solution to the problem. It will be noted that Mr. Sharpe has made provision for the installation of plumbing in the hope that at some later date running water will be made available on the reserve. I feel that this is particularly desirable but it will not be necessary to incur an expenditure for plumbing this year.

I would strongly recommend that if it is at all possible that this work be completed this year.

RE:- Repairs to Shulus Day School.

Mr. Okert has submitted the enclosed quotation on the proposed work.

He says that he will start work as soon as possible to have it completed while school is out if given the contract.

He is supposed to build a new school at Douglas Lake but as they are very slow with accepting his plan he assures me that our work will be first. I might say that he has proven to be very conscientious in his work and has made all his work to a good standard. With the exception of gyproc or other finishing material has used local lumber.

RE:- Shulus Indian Day School Teacherage.

Mr. Okert considers that the job can be done both cheaper and faster under contract. He uses 4 men and himself. His daily income is $52.40 per 8 hr. day. He uses power saws and concrete mixer. On contract he would assemble and cut in town by power and haul out to the school ready to go up. This in window and door casings alone would save many hours of time over hand sawing and fitting.

On day labour this work would all be done out on the job by hand as there is no power out of town. He has several jobs waiting on him and would much rather do this on contract at the figure stated, but if the Department insist will do it on a Day Labour Basis.

He is quite anxious to get at the job as he has a school to build at Douglas Lake. In my opinion it would be better to let him do it by contract and be free from the purchase of material with its numerous vouchers and accounts.

My time is so taken up this summer that I dread the thought of added work.

G. E. Sharpe,
Superintendent.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Addition to Shulus Indian Day School

We have for some time been considering what construction would best meet our requirements in the matter of accommodation for the teacher at the above-mentioned school and recently decided that an addition to the existing building would not only be most suitable but less costly.

For your information I am enclosing Supt. Sharpe's letter of June 22nd and enclosures, memorandum dated June 25th from Mr. Davey and further communications dated July 6th and 18th from Supt. Sharpe. You will note that we are in a position to secure the services of Mr. J. Okert, building contractor, who will remodel the building in accordance with his plan for the sum of $4900.00, which amount covers both material and labour. Mr. Okert is the only carpenter in the area and I doubt very much whether we can interest anyone outside the area in this small project. I would recommend that if at all possible his tender be accepted and that the work be put underway at the earliest possible date.

-W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The School Inspector for British Columbia feels that this plan would be an excellent solution to our requirements at Shulus, and I agree with Mr. Indian Commissioner Arneil's recommendation that his tender be accepted. It is, therefore, requested that the Minister approve the tender of Mr. Jack Okert of Merritt, British Columbia in the sum of $4,900. for the construction of a teacherage and additions to the Shulus Indian Day School.

Sir:

I have the honour to transmit herewith copy of report dated July 14th, by G. S. Pragnell, Inspector of Indian Agencies, with respect to the inspection of the Nicola Agency. In regard to item No. 4 in which the Inspector offers the suggestion for the provision of certain manual training equipment for use at the Day School at Shulus Reserve, I wish to say I have advised the Inspector that it is the policy of the Department that manual training accommodation be furnished to residential schools only, although an exception might be made where the day school attendance is very large, such as at Nanaimo. In the case of the Shulus School, however, I have examined the blue book and find that last year the attendance showed an average of 9 out of an enrolment of 14 - 7 boys and 7 girls. It is pleasing, however, to learn of the satisfactory work done by Mr. and Mrs. Fyall at this school and, if it is found that the attendance from now on is steady, the inclusion of an item such as suggested by the Inspector might be feasible of consideration in connection with next year's estimates and the Inspector has been advised to this effect.

Your obedient servant,

(SGD.) W. E. DITCHBURN.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE SHULUS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL ON OCTOBER 23, 1934.

Mr. Fyall has been here a very long time. He is not a Normal trained teacher, but he is trusted by the Indians. His main value to the Department lies in activities outside the actual laid down Programme of Studies. I particularly wish to see regular Manual Training started at this Indian Day School. If the Department would supply two sets of tools, as was done at Metlakatla Day School, and sufficient lumber for making useful articles, the whole costing less than $50.00, a very great advance in the educational value of the school would result.

Girls' Work:

I hope that the Department will supply the Singer Sewing Machine recommended above. Mrs. Fyall, who is paid nothing for her work, has rendered excellent service to the Indian girls by teaching them to sew, knit, etc. With a treadle sewing machine, the girls could be taught to make their own clothes, etc. I certainly believe that in out of the way Indian schools like this the vocational training is one of the most important things for the children. I, therefore, ask that a small sum be taken from the B. C. Special Grant for this purpose.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY DATED NOVEMBER 9, 1934, FORWARDED WITH ABOVE REPORT.

I wish to recommend that vocational training be given a trial at this school. I understand that when the Deputy Superintendent General visited the Metlakatla Indian Day School near Prince Rupert, and saw what we have done there, he was pleased with the result, and wished this manual training etc., carried on at other Indian day schools. Mr. Fyall is just the man to make a success of such training. Mrs. Fyall is doing splendid work with the girls.

I am certainly glad to report favourably on this little day school. I shall try to visit it more often in the future as requested by the teacher.
Ottawa, November 23rd, 1934.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Inspector Barry's report regarding his inspection of the Shulus Indian Day School on October 23rd, 1934.

Mr. Barry strongly recommends that manual training be started at this school and, for this purpose, he suggests that two sets of tools and sufficient lumber for making useful articles be purchased. Mr. Barry estimates that the cost of the equipment just mentioned would not exceed $50.00. You may incur an expenditure to this amount and, when forwarding vouchers, you should mark on them "Payable from B. C. Special".

You should communicate with Mr. Barry and ascertain what tools should be supplied. Mr. Fyall will, no doubt, assist you in choosing the proper lumber.

A sewing machine is being ordered by the Department for the Shulus Indian Day School from the Singer Sewing Machine Company and will be shipped to you.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

We have in our village 38 children over 6 years of age and by over 4 years of age and a large number under four.

The inlet abounds with salmon, halibut and herring for the taking.

There is a local saw mill from which building material can be purchased.

Dear Sir,

We the undersigned members of Skidegate band of Indians and councilors for the village, hereby make application to the Dept. through you for ourselves and our people, that a boarding school with accommodation for twenty-five or thirty children be opened in or near our village.

Skidegate Feb 1st 1911
Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith original petition, forwarded me by the Skidegate Band of Indians, with reference to the placing of a Boarding School on or near the Skidegate Reserve, in this Agency.

The Skidegate and Massett Bands are both anxious to have Boarding Schools, in order to allow their children to remain at their homes during the Fishing Season. It is plain that the demoralizing effect of the cannery life, on the young Indian, will mean the destruction of the race. They learn all that is bad there, and nothing for their good. They are away from their pastors and agents and are under no restraint. If we ever do anything to uplift the Indian, there is a surety that they must be kept in their homes. When they go away it is nothing but disease, demoralization and dead bodies we get, in return. Here they learn; are away from evil influences; have their Church and School to uplift them. We can watch and punish the erring and fit them from something that is now dragging them down,-to take their places in the land which so many of them seem fit to occupy.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

Reserve I append herewith, viz:- An application in duplicate, for the privilege sought should be made to the Indian Superintendent for the Province, through the local Indian Agent for the district in which it is contemplated to erect the building for school purposes, and carry on the same, etc.

Sir,

I find myself under the necessity of calling the attention of the Superintendent General to the course pursued by Mr. Indian Agent Todd, of the North-West Coast Agency, British Columbia, in regard to certain Indian schools conducted under the auspices of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Church. For several years past it has been a matter of common report from our Missionaries and others that Mr. Todd has in many ways shown himself to be unfriendly to the work of the Methodist Church. Some of these complaints have already been definitely stated in a communication laid before the Superintendent General by the Rev. Dr. Carman, and others, on behalf of the Methodist Church. In the present communication I refer to the case of two schools located respectively at Port Essington, and Skidegate, Queen Charlotte Islands, B.C.

In regard to the school at Port Essington, the facts are stated in a letter from the Rev. D. Jennings, missionary at that place, a copy of which I enclose herewith. Concerning the school at Skidegate, the facts are substantially as follows: Several years ago this school received the customary grant from the Department; after a time we found that remittances were not being received, and on enquiry being made at Ottawa, we were informed that no reports had been received from the Skidegate school for a length of time past, and consequently no grant had been made for its support. I at once wrote to the Rev. Mr. Crosby at Port Simpson and received a reply from him to the effect that he had reason...
To believe that reports had been regularly forwarded. Almost at the same time a letter came from Miss Ross, the teacher at Skidegate, written before she was aware of any complaint respecting the reports. Although not stating in so many words, the letter seemed to imply that reports had regularly been sent to the Agent, and I communicated the substance of that letter to the Department at Ottawa. During the present winter Mr Crosby wrote to me saying that Miss Ross had been unable to obtain forms for the quarterly reports, although she had written repeatedly to the Agent for them. It would seem that this matter has been corrected, for in a letter received this morning from Miss Ross, she intimates that school returns for September and December quarters have just been mailed to my address, though the latter quarter is defective because she had not sufficient blank forms.

Besides the direct financial loss to the Society, these things cause a good deal of annoyance to our Missionaries and Teachers, and also to those having the direction of the Missionary Society's affairs. It would be very gratifying indeed if something could be done to overcome these delays in the transmission of reports. This is especially necessary in some parts of the North-West and British Columbia where mail communication is to be had only at wide intervals. If the Agent instead of returning a report to the teacher on some trivial technicality, as in the case of the teacher at Port Essington, would forward the report to the Department drawing attention to the supposed discrepancy, much valuable time might be saved, and a good deal of annoyance avoided.

I am,

Sir,

With reference to securing the services of a Teacher for the Skidegate Indian Day School, I am in receipt of a letter from Rev. Dr. Spencer, in which he states: "I am anxious to get a good man and have a better salary paid. You know how hard it is to get a good man to take hold of one of these schools on $500 salary. I don't think the Department expects us to be able to secure the best teachers. Now if we had, say, $800 or $1,000, to offer a teacher, we would have a much better chance. A cheap teacher is, in my opinion, an expensive piece of business, because each year a number of boys and girls leave the school, being beyond school age. It is too bad to see how many go out without a working knowledge of English. If you know of any good man I would like to have his address."

In another letter Dr. Spencer states: "Mr. Haley was down to Vancouver and promised to secure, if possible, a good teacher for us. If he fails to secure one, there is at the Sand Spit a man with his wife and little girl. They came two weeks ago. Teaching is his hobby. He says he will fill a gap for us, if necessary, till we can secure a teacher. He would, I believe, do good service. He taught Indian children at Simpson for awhile. for teacher, we could get a man who has been teaching in Columbia College. I wish such a thing could be worked.*

In connection with the schools of this Agency, I might be permitted to make a few suggestions.

The two large schools are in districts where the cost of living is high. Even the Indians will not work for the cannery at less than $3.00 per day. They look for results, from teachers, and the kind obtainable, at a low salary, is only men who are looking for something better. Mr. McConkey, and Mr. Russell, were both giving satisfactory service; but Mr. McConkey asked for $1,000 a year, and Mr. Russell worked overtime, in the cannery.

I would respectfully suggest that the teachers receive $900 a year. The Massett Teacher has a house, at Massett Reserve; but is not provided for, by the Government, at Naden Harbour.

Having the largest school, the free rent would be a difference in his favour, above the teacher of the Skidegate School. The Indians are anxious to have good men stay with them, especially married men; but we cannot keep them. Teachers, without certificates, are allowed to have charge of the Provincial Day Schools, and they receive $80 per month, on Graham Island. The attendance at the White schools is small. Our teachers have a large attendance. The Massetts and Skidegates are willing to learn. They are progressive, and a credit to the Department, with good towns and showing more signs of advancement than any of the Indians on the Coast. The Bands are large, and they reside in only two places, Massett and Skidegate.

If it could be possible to engage first-class teachers the results would be remarkable.

I have the honour to report the receipt of the following, from Mr. A. C. Brown, Teacher of Skidegate Indian Day School, and the Rev. Dr. J. C. Spencer, formerly Missionary at Skidegate:

Mr. Brown's letter reads as follows:

"Dear Sir.—I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 28th and beg to inform you that the school is now out of my hands, the Conference having replaced me by Mr. Young, of Port Simpson Boys Home, who, I understand, is entering the ministry. I had not any intention of leaving the school, and Dr. Spencer never said a word about it to me and I did not say that I wanted to leave, hence the reason I asked for my holidays at the usual time. It's what I call a low down trick to play on a fellow; but I suppose the least said the better it will be. I closed school on June 6th as the rest of the Indians went away on the following Monday to the Skeena. The reason that the big girls were turned out of school was because they were constantly quarreling, one with the other, and generally causing a disturbance in the school. This was done at the request of the Council, who held a meeting and then sent them letters telling them that they must stay away from school if they could not behave themselves.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont."

The remainder of the Indians came over on the "Albert," W. Ross and Charles Jefferson being the only two families remaining in the village. I would have liked to have come over to see you, but it was a case of waiting around. I will write you again when I get below. (Sd.) A. C. Brown.*

Dr. Spencer's letter is as follows:-

"Dear Sir:-In reply to yours of June 2nd, which has just reached me, I may say that Mr. Brown did not resign. During the Winter and early Spring he spoke frequently as though he would like to be relieved. But, as you know, it is often difficult to find anyone between times to take up such work. He did not seem to get on at all well with the pupils. There was constant war in the school; for that reason I thought it would be well for us to try another. Besides that we have a Mr. Young here at Port Simpson, who has given good satisfaction in this big school and will, I feel sure, do the same at Skidegate. When school closed Mr. Brown had, apparently changed his mind, and would have been willing to stay on; but, for the sake of the school, I think a change is needed. Most of the Indians are on the Skeena and Mr. Young will spend holidays on the mainland and be at Skidegate in plenty of time to begin school. He is, I believe, B. A. and a studious man. Mr. Brown made no attempt at studying of any description. I am sorry I have neglected resigning myself but supposed that would be taken for granted. Yes, I hope to keep in touch with you for all that makes for the welfare of the Indians. (Sd.) J. C. Spencer.*

With regard to the above I beg to state that Mr. Brown, and Rev. Dr. Spencer, did not agree on many matters; but, when I visited Skidegate, no complaint was made against Mr. Brown, either by the Indians or the Missionary, at any time. The school was conducted and reported on in a satisfactory
Summer, so far as I could see or learn, and Mr. Brown appeared to be painstaking, sober and regular. I spent some time at Skidegate Reserve, last Winter, and visited the school frequently. When I heard that Mr. Brown had dismissed some of the older girl pupils, I asked for an explanation, in writing, and his answer is above. Mr. Brown did not care about taking up Missionary duties, in connection with teaching, and the salary was low, until recently, when it was increased. It is better to have a teacher there that will agree with the Missionary, considering that both live on the reserve; and the Department is not responsible for any of the troubles of the former Missionary and Teacher. We simply endeavoured to have the school conducted according to instructions, and it was, so far as I could see.

The Skidegate Indians are away. It is the time of the Summer Vacation, and no difficulties will arise over any lack of a teacher, for some time yet. He would have no pupils, if at Skidegate.

I understand that Mr. Young will be a very satisfactory gentleman, to act as teacher, and only regret that it is so difficult to retain teachers and others, on these islands.

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith "Agent's Report" on the Day Schools in this Agency.

As you will observe, both schools have been closed—one through the presence of "Whooping Cough" in Skidegate Village, and the other on account of the lack of pupils. In fact, but eight children were attending at Skidegate, when I last visited the School.

It is practically impossible to keep the children at school, during the good weather. They go and come; one day the family is on the reserve; the next day they go in boats to gardens, camps, mill towns, and away, here and there.

Year after year, we are compelled to shut down the day schools, at the beginning of May, and they are not opened, on the reserve again, until September, or October.

At times, when the canneries employ a number of the Indians, the teachers go there, and open school; but little advancement is made, and the children fall back, until we never have a child, the product of a day school, that shows any marked ability.

I have consulted with the recently appointed Anglican Missionary here, Rev. J. Gillett, and also with the Chief Counsellor, Alfred Adams. We have

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6413, file 843-1, part 2)
gene thoroughly into the question of education of the Indians, and find that the children must be kept at home, during the whole year, if they are to be properly educated. This can be done by having a central place, for the children to reside in, on the reserve, during the time the parents are away, earning their living. Rev. Mr. Gillett is new at the meeting of the Synod, and intends bringing up the question there. Chief Counsellor Adams is also at the meeting, and will give the Indian side of the question. With the assistance of the Missionary and Chief Counsellor, it is possible to work out a plan that will be acceptable both to the Department and the Church authorities. We have laid the groundwork, and will place before you our conclusions, after the return of Messrs. Gillett and Adams.

The school question has been one that requires our best efforts. The Indians are now surrounded by loggers and White fishermen, in camps and towns. The children must be kept away from the influences found there. If we must advance the Indian, it is wrong to have children of tender age running around towns and camps, doing nothing. They learn no good there. If we can devise some means of keeping the children on the reserve, during the Summer months, we will solve the education and saving of the Hydahs.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

The Field Matron and Nurse and also the teacher of the Indian Day School, were both absent during my visit, and I am not aware whether they will return. They did not inform me that it was their intention to leave the islands, simply taking their departure. I found an Indian, Henry Green, in charge of the Day School, and he informed me that he was placed in charge by the Missionary. Shortly after my arrival, the Missionary and his wife left the reserve, for the South, and I learned the medicine is locked up in his residence. At present we have no whites looking after the Skiddgates, although there is communication by telephone between the Reserve and my office. Fortunately there is little illness. The School will be closed, in a short time, on account of the absence of the Indians, at their fishing grounds and gardens, and there will be no necessity for a Field Matron and Nurse, and School Teacher, on this reserve, during the summer, as the place is, practically, deserted, from the middle of May until September. Miss Wharton and Mrs. Pakeley, were both ill, during the Winter, and that may account for their absence. Apparently, they did not consider it advisable to give notice of their intention to leave, for the reason, as I understand it, that they were not engaged here, and the responsible heads were those who gave them the positions. The acting Indian Teacher appeared to fill the vacancy, very acceptably, and was greatly interested in the work, when I reached Skidegate. I visited the schoolhouse often, and found that the children appeared to advance, and were under better discipline than on any other occasion. It would be advisable to temporarily appoint Henry Green to take charge of this school, during the Winter months, and place him under the regulations governing the two Indian teachers of Massett Indian Day School.

Ferrier, Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools, under whose auspices this school is conducted, is endeavouring to secure a suitable teacher and nurse to take charge of this School, after the Summer vacation."

In connection with the appointment of a Teacher, and a Field Matron and Nurse, for this School, permit me to ask that, before appointments are made, the parties willing to accept be given distinctly to understand conditions, at Skidegate, and that the Field Matron and Nurse will know, beforehand, what is expected of her, and whether fuel and light will be granted, or not. Attending to Indians, on these islands is a very difficult position for any lady to fill. Living on an Indian reserve, with high cost for everything, "no

The Assistant Deputy General Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6413, file S43-1, part 2)
the many disadvantages met with, is a strain on any lady filling the position of Field Matron and Nurse. The School Teachers have their duties defined, and the responsibilities connected with their offices is easily understood. It is quite different with a Field Matron and Nurse. With no doctor in the neighbourhood; irregular means of communication with outside parts; dealing with a peculiar band of Indians that claim to be more civilized than the ordinary Indian, and with the independence not found in other Indians—the position is one not to be envied. It would be advisable that the newly appointed Field Matron and Nurse should understand, in written instructions, her responsibilities, and her duties.

In asking for the appointment of Field Matrons and Nurses, some years ago, my aim was to have someone, on the ground, ready to assist sick and indigent Indians and to endeavour to suppress tuberculosis. Indian women were first appointed, and I found no fault with their work. They were dismissed, and White women appointed, at the instance of the then Inspector of Indian Agencies. The work of Field Matrons was then included; but their principal work has been attending to the sick. They have a great deal to do in this work, in fact, it takes up a great deal of their time, and I find they are more useful, in this respect, than Medical Officers, who visit the reserve, periodically, while the Nurse is always on hand. Recently, at Skidegate, the former Field Matrons and Nurses understood they were under the direction of the Church authorities, and although we had telephonic communication to the reserve, we heard little of conditions on the reserve, until the monthly report was submitted. The fuel and light question arose, and I was blamed for not supplying same. I was
also told, by the Missionary, that the Field Matron and Nurse was appointed by the Church authorities, and was responsible to them. If this is correct, I would be pleased to know that my duty, in connection with the Field Matron and Nurse, is to simply inspect, as in the case of teachers, and report to the Department. All I am anxious about is the good of the Indian, morally, socially and intellectually. Any instructions given, in the past, emanated from the Department. Without a medical officer, a great deal of responsibility rests on the Field Matron and Nurse. If a lady teacher is appointed, the Field Matron work might be accomplished by her. With these Indians, a lady teacher has a difficult position. The children "rule the home," and would rule "the school," if permitted. The last teacher had difficulty with them.

A Returned Soldier, for teacher, and his wife, as Field Matron and Nurse, would be preferable, if qualified persons could be obtained. Personally, I would be pleased to see Rev. J. C. Spencer, and his daughter, return to Skidegate. Miss Spencer is a qualified Nurse, and Rev. Dr. Spencer was medical Officer of this Band, for some years, and gained the respect and esteem of the Indians. It is to be regretted that he ever left the Band.

Your Obedient Servant,

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith Monthly Reports on Massett and Skidegate Indian Day Schools, for the month of November, 1919.

During the early part of the month, I visited Skidegate school. Found Miss Lilian McDonald in charge. This lady was making the first attempt to handle Indian pupils, and complained of conditions, as found. It is difficult for a lady to control Indian children, on outside reserves. Much is expected by the parents; but they do not discipline their own offspring, and seldom visit the school. As the School is under the auspices of the Methodist Church, the Missionary, who lives in the adjacent house, might be requested to visit the School, and assist the Teacher, in maintaining discipline. It is difficult for a woman to teach Indian children, at any time or place. Miss McDonald is giving every attention to her pupils, and is to be commended for her efforts; but informs me that it is not her intention to remain.

At the Massett Indian Day School, the two Indian teachers are making good progress. We have introduced the making of baskets, an almost lost art amongst the Indians, and the girls are taking quite an interest in the work. During the time the Indian woman is teaching the girls, Teacher Adams instructs the boys in singing. These Indians are musical, and many of them have instruments in their houses. The attendance at the

The Aest. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Massett Indian Day School is good, considering that so many families are absent, taking advantage of the fur market prices, the logging, cannery work and other occupations throughout the country.

I would like to see a Night School started, for the men, and elder boys and girls, which would be well attended, during the Winter months, especially at Massett; also a Library, where the men and boys would pass the long Winter evenings, receiving instruction. These institutions would benefit the Indians, materially. They will not take the initiative, in anything for their benefit. Old and young need instruction, in many ways. The Church is building a new Rectory; while the Indians are constructing a new place of worship. The old Church might be used, for Library purposes. The Indians have a Hall, which is falling into decay, where they might have an athletic club, and library; but they will not contribute the funds for the upkeep of such institutions. The Council of 1919 has been more or less scattered, working in various places, and little has been done by the Councillors, to advance their fellow members of the communities.

We are now at the stage when the Indian problem must be considered, with these affecting the Whites. No community suffered less than the Indians of these islands, during the war. Their education has produced diverse characters, from the older generation, and the future is fraught with many difficulties, now that immigration is tending towards these islands. The pity of it is that they must leave their homes, during the Summer, to obtain employment, feed and means to live, during the Winter.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge your letter of February 2nd instant, with reference to the arrangement of classes in Skidegate Indian Day School, and the request of Miss Blanche E. Ward, for permission to divide the classes, in order to teach the senior classes during the forenoon, and the three junior classes, during afternoons.

During my recent visit, to Skidegate Reserve, met the Teacher; but, unfortunately, Miss Ward was taken ill, and was under the care of Dr. Palmer. It was apparent that Miss Ward was exerting herself, beyond her strength, and it is probable that Miss Ward will not continue, as teacher, after this year. This is to be regretted, Miss Ward is one of the most conscientious teachers, and has done a great deal to advance the pupils. I agree with you, and would be sorry to lose the services of Miss Ward. I would recommend that her request be granted. It would mean less strain, on the teacher, and the results would be even better than teaching the whole of the children, at one time. The Indian children come and go, with their parents. During the winter months, almost all of the families are on the one reserve, when Spring opens, they go off to their camping grounds. During the Summer, they are at the canneries, and the fishing grounds. During the Fall, they gather fish, fruit and other food, for the Winter.

For a few months, they overcrowd the day school; the teacher is then overtaxed. If the Indians talked the English language, in their homes, we might expect good results, even from day school teaching; but the older generation continues to converse, in the Haida language; yet it is remarkable that many of the children are more than anxious to learn. Where we now have over one hundred children, at two Day Schools, and a large number, at Coqualeetza, it is to be regretted that we have no residential school, in this locality, and no boarding school, ready to take those desirous of attending.

Sir,

I beg to submit copy of a letter received from Miss Blanche E. Ward, Teacher of Skidegate Indian Day School, with reference to conditions, on the Skidegate Indian reserve:

(Copy.)

Skidegate Mission,
Queen Charlotte Islands, B.C.,
January 13th, 1923.

"Mr. Thomas Deasy,
Indian Agent,
Massett, B.C.

"Dear Mr. Deasy:- I received your letter last night. Thank you very much for all your good wishes. It is indeed refreshing to receive such kind words, at the close of a strenuous week, and I appreciated them very much. I am sorry to tell you that I am finding my work too great a tax on my strength-about collapsed, this week, and began to fear that I would have to leave, at once. However, if you do not mind, I am going to try teaching the four senior classes in the morning, and the three junior classes in the afternoon, and see if that will relieve the pressure, so that I can continue. I would be sorry to leave the children without a teacher, so early in the year, for many of them did not start school until October. The plan, if feasible, will give the children more teaching than they are getting at present, and my hours will be lengthened, rather than shortened, for the first bell will ring at 4:00, as usual, and I am afraid that I will not be able to get through until 4:15; then the blackboard work will keep me till six. However, I will not have over forty children tucked into twenty-five desks (double), many of which are too small for one pupil, let alone two. The discipline under these conditions is such a constant strain my health will not stand it any longer. As I am trying to somewhere near approximate, the course of studies, as outlined by the Vancouver Schools, I cannot allow the discipline to slip, and thought if I had the children in two groups, I would not be working under such a tension. I may be mistaken in thinking it will relieve me in any way, but some such plan has been tried in Vancouver, when there was much overcrowding. However, a fresh teacher was always put on, for the afternoon work, though the first one may have started earlier than mine. I am so glad you are so soon to visit us, when we can talk over the problems. This letter will give you an opportunity to think over the matter before you come. The school has been very comfortable, throughout the coldest weather, thanks to the improvements you had done and the excellent wood.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa."
The Stove Pipes are about burnt through, we need 12 new lengths, A" Pipe, and a new Elbow. I wonder if it would be possible to get the Pipes in the new ten-foot lengths, so that they would be safe and much more easily cleaned? I hope you have a good trip when coming to Skidegate. Unfortunately, my Quarterly Report would not give any accurate idea as the attendance was small at the beginning of October, and that made the Quarter's Attendance low. (Sd.) Blanche E. Ward.

It is my intention to visit Skidegate Reserve on the 21st inst., when I will interview Miss Ward on the above. The young lady takes a great deal of interest in the education of the Indian children, and her resignation would be a great loss to both the Department and pupils. The plan suggested would be possible; but the question of the disposition of the children, during the daytime, when outside the schoolhouse, is one to be considered. We have them, for only a few months, in each year, and only for a few hours, each day-five days in each week. During the spring, and summer months, they forget a great deal of what they learn, during the few winter months. Parents, and children, talk the "Haida" language, at their homes, and when outside the schoolhouse. What is needed is a Boarding School for the large number of children of both the Masset and Skidegate Bands, increasing in numbers, and without a Boarding School, in the whole of this great northern country, we send a number to Chililack to the Coqualeetsa Industrial Institute, hundreds of miles away; out, where we guarantee an attendance of over one hundred pupils, in a Boarding School, in this neighbourhood, of children, eager to learn the English language, the need of such a school is apparent.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th March ultimo, with regard to "the petition or Skidegate council," requesting the appointment of a "second teacher, for Skidegate Indian Day School."

There is but one "class room" connected with the school building, on Skidegate Indian Reserve.

During the winter months, the attendance is large; but it must be remembered that the Indians of this Agency are without any industrial plants, near the reserve, while the families leave, for the canneries and fishing grounds, in the summer. An assistant teacher might be employed, during the five months, from the end of October; but, in my opinion, the Indians will again be away from the reserve, during the coming summer, and will not leave their young children, with no-one to care for them.

It is possible, the lady teacher is over-taxed, during the fall and winter months, although no complaint comes from that source. The Indians of this agency require a residential school, where the children would remain, the year round, when the parents are engaged, in canneries, and while away, fishing.

The Massette and Skidegates take a great interest in the education of their young, and should be encouraged. They have forty-six pupils, at Oogma-leetza Institute, and could readily send one hundred more, to a residential school.

Your obedient servant,
(Thomas Denny)
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir,

In accordance with your request I found it possible to spend a few hours in your native schools at Skidegate and Massett, after attending to the inspection of my own schools at these points. I beg to give you in a friendly way my finding as follows:

SKIDEGATE: I have frequently visited this school in the seven years that I have spent in the north. Indeed with the single exception of last year when this school was not in operation during May, I have always looked in upon the work. After these six visits I almost feel as if the school were part of my regular work. This year, however, I was free to go more thoroughly into the work, since you yourself and the Council invited me to do so. You will therefore please regard this as a friendly criticism and not in any way official.

This is the best small native school that I have ever visited. I attribute this to the class of teacher that you have almost invariably employed. To Miss Ward, who, I believe, was the first to use at Skidegate, modern methods of teaching; great credit is due. Her successors, Misses MacKay, Rood, Young, Bertrand and McRea, have, as far as their individual ability and experience allowed, followed in her footsteps, and have demonstrated to me that it is quite possible to get response from native children when the work is made interesting. Candidly, were the white schools staffed with the type of teacher that I have so often seen in native schools, I am inclined to think that the interest and progress would be at a low ebb. It is a real pleasure to see the response to modern teaching in this school.

In some native schools that I have visited there has been no definite objective, no well defined Course of Study. In Skidegate for at least six years your teachers have endeavoured to follow the B. C.
Course of Study. If compulsory attendance and punctuality were insisted upon as in our white schools, this would soon be productive of even more marked results.

There are too many enrolled for one teacher. In a school the size of this at least two teachers should be employed. This would mean an additional room. The present building is commodious but the lighting is wrong, and doors and windows are so placed that only about one-fourth of the necessary blackboard space is available. In a native school even more than in a white school, should there be the maximum of blackboard space. In this way many children may be working at the board at the same time under supervision and the efficiency of a teacher is multiplied many times.

A library of supplementary readers with a score or more copies of each book would be found very useful. These books should not be taken home, but should be used in the schoolroom under the teacher's direction. Indeed it would seem to me a necessity to have such a library of well chosen readers. Dent's Canadian History Readers I to VIII, by Miss Dickie, would be of value, especially III to VI.

Your teacher, Miss McRea, is not a disciplinarian. She has not made more mistakes than the average young teacher makes in her first school, and after being several hours in the school I feel that she should give better service, since I have candidly pointed out her errors and commended her good points. Should you engage two teachers for next year, Miss McRea would be much better with the lower division than with the larger pupils.

Since you yourself visit this school regularly, I need not point out that the pupils are clean and that the room itself is clean and tidy.

MASSETT: There is here a large building with two good rooms. While the blackboard space is greater than in the Skidegate schoolroom, it is not so great as a modern school requires. Our ideal today is windows on one side of the room and blackboards on the other three sides.

Most of the children were with their parents at the Tow Hill Clam Cannery. At this point I met with the teacher and children and saw enough of the work to assure me that both Miss Stella Shopland and Miss Dorothy Shopland have proceeded in a modern way to instruct the hundred or more pupils in their charge. It would seem that in these young ladies you have efficient, faithful teachers.
Were this a Provincial School we would employ three qualified teachers. It is our policy to employ a teacher for less than 40 pupils, two for between 40 and 80, and three for between 80 and 120. With the native children it would seem to me that 25 or 30 to a room would be quite sufficient until the schools had attained a higher standing. I do not see how one could look for really efficient work unless at least one more room were added to this building.

My remarks re attendance, punctuality, and library in my report of Skidegate would also apply here.

In closing I beg to assure you that having the time at my disposal, it was a pleasure to look more intimately than usual into your interesting schools. At the same time I should like you to regard this as a friendly criticism and not in any way official.

Yours very truly,

H.C. Fraser
Inspector of Schools.

Sir:

I have the honour to forward herewith the Agent's report for the Massett, Roe Hill and Skidegate Schools, for the month of May. I am also enclosing Mr. Inspector Fraser's letter to the Agent regarding these schools. His remarks on the Massett and Skidegate Schools regarding the number of teachers required expresses the need which the Agent has seen for some time, namely, three qualified teachers for Massett School, and two for Skidegate. Massett this year had over one hundred on the roll, and Skidegate over forty. There will be more in both schools next term.

If the suggestion for three qualified teachers for the Massett school is carried out, it will be necessary to have another room added, such as the Department's original plans called for. I realise that there was not anything provided for in the estimates for 1928-29, to take care of this, so that I suppose the new room could not be added this year. However, the present school could be rearranged so as to make three rooms with very little expense. All that is required is the partition between the large room and the cloak room moved, and two new doors. The enclosed plan of the present school and a sketch of the alteration will show what I mean. If nothing can be done this year, possibly the old Church could be used, as before the new school was built. With a little renovating it would do temporarily, and this would be better than disturbing the present arrangements in the school.

The Skidegate school is quite an old building, I believe originally a church, and a new one will be required in the near future. It is large enough to allow for a temporary partition, so as to accommodate two teachers.

The greatest difficulty is in getting the attendance large enough to require the number of teachers mentioned, during the months of September, May and June. But it could be done from the middle of October to the end of April, with a little more rigid enforcement of Sec. 10 of the Indian Act. The Skidegate attendance has been good for the time the people were in the village. Massett attendance has also been very good, but would have been better if it had not been for the sicknesses. The people themselves are taking more interest in school affairs and the Agent feels with Mr. Fraser, that if the Indian schools were conducted on the same lines as the White Schools, the results would compare favourably. There would then be no reason why there should not be pupils from these schools taking the Entrance exams every year.

There would be no necessity for hiring the extra teachers for September, or after April. I understand that there are plenty of teachers in B.C. who could be obtained at any time. As far as the present teachers are concerned, Miss Dorothy Shopland will be coming back, but Miss Stella Shopland hopes to go to University. Miss Mahie will not be returning to Skidegate. Shall I make arrangements to secure a teacher to replace Miss Shopland. I suppose the United Church will have the privilege of nominating someone for Skidegate.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Mr. Watson's knowledge of the teachers is trustworthy, and he is in touch with all in B.C. who are looking for schools.

Dear Sir,

Since June of this year I have been in correspondence with the Department regarding the removal of the teacher at Skidegate. By Departmental letter of August 9th I was informed that the Department had approved of Miss Wright's re-engagement for the coming school year. As the Church Authorities had arranged with Miss Wright to resume duties it would be difficult at the present time to make a change.

Apparently the Church authorities are using Skidegate as a place for the teacher instead of finding a suitable teacher for Skidegate. The United Church must have known that Miss Wright was not giving satisfaction, as when Mr. Barner was in Skidegate in February of this year, the Council were very emphatic in their remarks to him regarding a change of teacher. Whatever the Church authorities' attitude, the Department has approved of their action and ignored the advice of their Agent, and it therefore reflects on his judgment and ability. I have no objection to the United Church having the privilege of nominating a teacher, but when they insist on someone who is not giving satisfaction, and is not up-to-date in her methods, I must voice my protest.

If it is the policy of the Department to accept the recommendations of the United Church Board of Home Missions, irrespective of the views and advice of their Agent, then I can only say that I cannot remain as their Agent. The sooner I know their policy in this matter the better.

However, if the Department has approved of Miss Wright only because there is no other way out at the present time, I would suggest that a second teacher be appointed for Skidegate, the duties to commence the first of November. According to the recent Census, there should be over forty children at school, and

After our conversation concerning the possibility of Mrs. Wark handling all the pupils in this school herself, I wrote to Mr. Gillett, the Indian Agent, asking for his opinion in regard to the matter.

His suggestion - which has just arrived - is that we hire a second teacher for seven months, October to April, inclusive. He says that the people do not get back from fishing until almost October, and sometimes they begin to leave again in April. In addition, there is the possibility that five or six children may go to Coqualeetza this fall.

Mr. Barner and I are quite satisfied with this suggestion, and if it meets with your approval we will proceed to find a teacher who is willing to accept an appointment on this basis. Could you let me know, in your reply, what salary rate would be allowed?

Yours very sincerely,

Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, addressed to Mr. Sutherland, of this Department, regarding the appointment of a second teacher at the Skidegate Indian Day School during the coming fall and winter months. In this connection I have to say that the Department received a communication from Mr. Gillett, the local Indian Agent, regarding the matter.

In our reply, it was pointed out that the average attendance is 42 pupils and that it was considered one teacher should be able to handle this number. The Agent was informed, further, that our funds this year are so limited that it is necessary to curtail expenditure at every possible point. The Department requested him to give further consideration to the necessity for a second teacher for approximately a five or six month period and to state if, in his opinion, the appointment of this teacher was really necessary.

Mr. Gillett requested a grant of $100 to cover the cost of transportation in sending six children to Coqualeetza. In this connection he was informed that the Department would be unable to provide the funds required.

It was suggested to him that, if any action is necessary, it would incur less expense to provide a second teacher for the period mentioned above than to send a number of children to Coqualeetza and provide the per capita grant for them.

When a further report is received from Mr. Agent Gillett, a decision will be given regarding the appointment of an additional teacher, and you will be advised. In any event, it is considered, if it is necessary to engage a second teacher, that her duties should not commence before November first next, and that it should be possible to secure a suitable teacher at a salary of $80 or $85 per teaching month, less the deduction of 10%.
