EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE SKIDEGATE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL - (Date of Inspection May 29/36).

I wish further to recommend that this Skidigate Indian Day School be not opened till October 1st each year and that it be closed on May 31st yearly, but that during the period October to May inclusive the TWO TEACHERS be employed. This would be a very much better educational arrangement than the present one of opening with one teacher for Senior and Junior children in one room, going on in November to two teachers and then having only one teacher for both Senior and Junior children in June. The attendance in September and June would not be sufficient to make such a mix up of teachers and pupils a worth while practice.

While I do not like the practice of having one teacher living alone in this village, the conditions are not quite as bad as they are in Massett, and the fact that the Field Matron, Mrs. Gladstone, lives quite near makes things much better. There is, however, I have every reason to believe, considerable drinking among the Indians in Skidigate at present and the Department certainly takes quite a risk in permitting single girls to live alone in these villages. Two teachers from October to May, inclusive, would solve the difficulty.

EXTRACT FROM MR. BARRY'S LETTER DATED MAY 30, 1936, ACCOMPANYING THE ABOVE REPORT.

I have recommended in this report that school be not opened till most of the Indians are back from fishing on say October 1st and that it be closed at the end of May. If my recommendation of having both teachers here from the opening on October 1st till the close on May 31st be followed, the girls will be much safer, and far better educational work can be done. The present practice of moving children from teacher to teacher is not good and is holding back the school.
Mr. Philip Phelan,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am very sorry to report that Miss Bunice Phillips arrived back in Vancouver after her year's work at Queen Charlotte tired and run-down. Her doctor claims that she is an incipient T.B. case, and has ordered her to take a year's rest. She has therefore asked us for leave of absence for one year which we are reluctantly granting.

Something unique happened in connection with the Skidegate School this year, because we received a letter from the Chief and Council expressing appreciation of the work of these teachers both in the classrooms and in the extra-curriculum activities. Most of the letters we get from our Indian Reserves are complaints.

I would like to suggest that Miss Vera F. Weaver should be appointed as the ten-months' teacher at Skidegate for the ensuing academic year beginning September 1st, and as a supply for the seven-months' teacher I would like to nominate Miss C. A. Vanderveen. She holds a First Class B. C. Certificate obtained at the Vancouver Normal. Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to my report on the Skidegate Indian Day School forwarded to you on May 15th last from Tlell, I have now received Departmental letter 157-11-1 dated June 21st and a copy of a letter from the Acting Indian Agent dated Massett, May 27th 1937.

The Superintendent of Welfare and Training asks for comments in regard to the closing of the above mentioned school during the months of September and June, which was the recommendation made in my report on this school on a previous occasion.

With great respect I would first point out that to me the discussion of the administration of the school with the Indian Council appears a great mistake.

As pointed out on other occasions the Indians of the Queen Charlotte Islands wrongly consider that the schools are paid for out of Indian funds and that they as Indians should have the decision as to what should be taught in the schools, how they should be conducted, etc.

Mr. Phillips has very little experience of Indians in general and of the Skidegate Indians in particular. He has little or no knowledge of school administration, and while I regret that he now appears to have come to an opposite opinion than that expressed when he discussed the matter with me during my visit to the Queen Charlottes, I simply am unable to modify my own professional recommendation in the matter.

To take up in detail the remarks of Mr. Phillips is a very difficult matter, as I do not understand what Mr. Phillips means in the third paragraph of his letter, nor do I understand his reference to the need for a third teacher, or what his reference to the Massett Indian Day School means.

It will be best for me to indicate again the reasons which prompted my recommendation of an eight month school year.

| Senior Room Average Attendance |
|-------------------------------|
| September 1934 12.31          |
| September 1935 16.55          |
| September 1936 17.78          |
| June 1935 10.16               |

During the above months all the children were in the Senior Room and only one teacher was employed.

May I say that in Skidegate the majority of the children most certainly do not come home early in September as stated by the Council.
It is a very bad practice to start small children with one teacher, the senior one, as has been done in Skidegate, and then in October or November have them go into another room and restart work with the other teacher. I do not believe that any competent authority on education would recommend such a practice, and it is mainly this foolish procedure that I understood that the Indian Affairs Branch had decided to abolish, hence my remark in the second last paragraph of Page 5 of my Skidegate report dated May 15, 1937.

The old procedure was for all the remaining pupils to again be taken together in the Senior Division in June thus destroying all chance of carrying the work of the senior division to a successful conclusion just before the High School and other Tests.

These remarks also apply to Massett, though the actual attendance figures are different and as given in my reports. In September 1926 it happened for I understand the first time and due to failure of fishing, that there were enough children to warrant Mr. Collison opening the two rooms at Massett together and on September 1st.

It is very important that one teacher be not sent to live in either Massett or Skidegate BY HERSELF.

I would not object to the opening of the two rooms at either Massett or at Skidegate on September 1st this year if the Indian Affairs Branch considers this the best course, nor do I object to the same two rooms being kept open in June 1938. There are not in normal years enough pupils to justify keeping the rooms open in June, and for the other reasons given in my reports the teacher of the senior room should certainly not be left in the village by herself.

What Mr. Phillips means by the statement that the junior class will be over 60 unless we have a third teacher I do not know. I may say that my remarks and recommendations were not based on the actual number in school when I inspected as Mr. Phillips would have seen had he consulted the copy of my reports in his possession before he wrote to the Indian Affairs Branch.

My recommendation is still to open Senior and Junior Divisions in Massett and Skidegate on October 1st and to close these schools on May 31st yearly. The progress of the pupils will not be retarded in any way, regardless of the opinions of non professional persons, and the wishes of Indians whose one aim is to have the children attend a Residential School if possible or if that is impossible get rid of their children for as long as possible in the day schools.

I hope that by the time of my next visit to the Queen Charlotte Islands in May 1938 a permanent Indian Agent will have been appointed and I can then explain in detail to him just why the recommendations were made in my reports which the Indian Affairs Branch knows were with a view to lessening the possibility of a criminal attack on one of our teachers by drunken Indian youths.

I certainly hope that this explanation will carry some weight with the Director of Welfare and Training, and I would ask you to add your own recommendations.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

My dear Doctor McGill:

I have to thank you for your letter of December 2nd. I quite appreciate your statements concerning the employment of qualified teachers. But really both Mr. Bryant and Mr. Kinley are not without qualifications. Mr. Bryant has a number of official qualifications though he does not possess a B.C. Teachers Certificate. One particular training he possesses is perhaps the most useful thing in an Indian School. He has a natural gift in mechanics and has developed his school along that line in an unusual degree. Besides, even Mr. Barry must agree that in ordinary school work he has been outstanding. As for Mr. Kinley, he has taken two terms at the Summer School in Victoria under Mr. Barry's instruction. It is my confirmed conviction that the Department is most fortunate in having two such men in its employ, not only as teachers but as an influence for good on the reservations. I very sincerely hope you will find it expedient to retain them in their positions at their respective places.

As to the new work at Kitwancool and Kisgagas, I note that you think favourably about it. Both these places are so isolated and accommodation so poor that we could hardly ask any white person to go there. It seems to me that the only immediate thing to do would be to get hold of the most capable native and try him out in the work and in the meantime try to find a young native and get him properly trained for the work.

I have, as my previous letter informed you, a couple of natives who have unusual education who could do some good work until we could obtain better qualified men. I have at least one such man in view. One qualification necessary is that any teacher at these places would have to be able to speak the local language. This restricts a choice. A white qualified teacher at these places seems to be out of the question. I do not know where such a person could be found who would be able and willing to stick it.
McGill.

You mention in your letter that it was your intention to recommend a grant be made to both of these school immediately after the opening of the school year in 1938. Does this mean that the grant will be available at the beginning of 1938 and will it be available for the men I have mentioned, Mr. Wale and Mr. Williams?

Thanking you again for the informative letter you sent and wishing you and yours a happy Christmas and New Year,

I am,

Yours faithfully,

G. A. Rix,
Bishop of Caledonia.

I would not recommend that Miss Manson be relieved of her work at the present time. She should be given another chance to make good here. If her next report is still unsatisfactory it may be necessary to make a change of teachers in this division.

Mrs. Moses is leaving at the end of the term I understand, and will seek work in a provincial school. She has been in charge of Division 1 for about three years.

I would recommend that regular monthly visits be paid to this school by the local Indian Agent. Dear Sir,

I have been teaching at the Skidegate Day School for the past three years and am now about to begin my fourth. During the past few years our salaries have been slowly decreased to the point where it is almost impossible to live here.

In view of these facts, may I respectfully request that my salary be increased to the minimum which, I believe to be $1,200 per annum. Another small detail is that I was appointed to the school and expected to assume full responsibility as Principal which I did. I understand that the Principal's salary was $10.00 per month more than the usual salary. In the past three years, my salary has been the same as the Junior Teacher's and yet I have been acting in the capacity as Principal.

If it is possible to make some adjustment, Sir, would you be so kind as to let me know as soon as it is convenient for you so that I may make my plans accordingly.

Thanking you for your indulgence and hoping that you can see it possible to make an increase, I remain,

Sincerely yours,

John H. Habkirk

P.S. May I ask a question in this letter? Are any of our taxes being deducted from the source for the past three years? I have been billed for an additional $2.84 which I cannot compute.

I wish to submit a brief resume of my recent trip to Prince Rupert and The Queen Charlotte Islands.

xx xx xx

QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY

Skidegate

Mr. Phillips accompanied me to Skidegate where a meeting was held with the council and visits made to the day school and some of the Indian homes. While here I also called on Mrs. Gladstone, our field matron, and the local United Church Missionary, the Rev. Mr. Afleck. The meeting with the council was on the whole quite satisfactory and matters on which information was requested were dealt with, these having mainly to do with medical service, preparation of income tax returns and the Indian Day School. No requests for relief were submitted nor complaints made against the Agent.

Certain improvements and repairs to the day school building are necessary and some work is also required to the teacher's residence. I instructed the Agent to prepare a list of these needs and secure an estimate of the costs involved in order that if possible some of the repairs could be undertaken during the months of July and August. The teacher's residence is a large, poorly constructed building and, in my opinion, should not have been acquired by the Department. It will be costly to maintain properly and it might be better to either dispose of it or tear it down and build a smaller new house in replacement as the cost of remodelling would probably equal the cost of a suitable new building. A small new teacher's residence for this Reserve might be included in our post-war program of worthwhile works.

It is doubtful if Miss Mackie, principal of the Indian day school, will continue at Skidegate after the close of the current school year as she is not enjoying good health and has been advised by the doctor to take a year's rest. Miss Mackie had done excellent work for use at Skidegate and is highly esteemed by the Indian people. It will be extremely difficult to replace her. She assured me, however, that she would be glad to seek employment with us should she decide to resume teaching on regaining her health.

(over)
I spent some time with the field matron, Mrs. Gladstone, R.N., who although somewhat dissatisfied with the salary we are paying her, still carries on and is doing very good work. At the time of my visit she was busy fixing up the new dispensary which is now located in the teacher's residence. A small expenditure for material and labour required to complete the painting and installation of shelving in the dispensary was authorized. Mrs. Gladstone reported that there was very little sickness in the village and that on the whole the health of the Indian was quite good.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

I have the honour to report as follows for the Queen Charlotte Agency, B.C., for the Quarter ending June, 1946.

EDUCATIONAL:

The Schools of both the Massett and Skidegate Reserves were visited several times each during the months. At the Skidegate school the teachers of both rooms, have made quite an improvement with their pupils during their terms, and it is regretted that Miss Merrett is being transferred to another school, however we are lucky in having Miss Strong return in her place, she too being a very capable teacher, Miss Mackie the Junior room teacher is staying for another term.

At the Massett school both the Senior and Junior teachers are not returning, both have done very well since they took over in February, however in conversation with Bishop Gibson, who was here on a visit, I was informed that he was sure that he would be able to recommend two teachers for this school for September both the Massett teachers were very active in social work and were very well liked by the Natives.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
REPORT FOR MARCH QUARTER

EDUCATIONAL:

The schools of both the Massett and Skidegate Reserves were visited several times each month. At the Skidegate school the teacher of the senior room has her class well disciplined, also in this class manual training has been introduced, and the boys have made a bookcase with doors and shelves for their room. I have recommended that tools be purchased for their use, to encourage them in this work. At the Massett school both the teachers commenced their duties in February, and are doing very well with their classes. They are very active in social work on the Reserve, have a teenage canteen and a kindergarten for those under school age under their supervision. The junior teacher (Mrs. Conroy) was taken out by plane March 17th with a throat affection to Prince Rupert, but returned to her duties March 28th. Both teachers are very well liked by the Indians of the Reserve.

B. T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

XX XX XX

Educational:

The Schools of both the Massett and Skidegate Reserves were visited several times each month. At the Skidegate Reserve the Teachers of both the Senior and Junior rooms appear to have things well in hand, and it was noted that the discipline in both rooms are much better than in previous years, a Christmas Concert was held at the Community Hall by the pupils which was very good according to the Council, the parents were particularly pleased with the children. At the Massett school, we only had one teacher, (Mrs Fray) who took both senior and Junior rooms morning and afternoon respectively, Mrs Fray was a very good teacher and a good disciplinarian and was very well liked by the pupils, however Mrs Fray was taken out by plane on the 17th of December to Hospital for an operation, her complaint is "Ascites" and the Field Matron has informed me that she will not be returning to teach at Massett, the school of course is closed down.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING SEPTEMBER 30th, 1945, ON QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY

Education: The schools of both the Massett and Skidegate Reserves were closed during July and August, during which repairs and cleaning were done. I visited both schools during September; two new teachers were at the Skidegate school (although Miss Mackie was Junior teacher here before). Miss Merritt is the New Senior teacher and appears to be a very capable person, taking a great interest in all matters pertaining to the welfare of the children and the school etc. The Natives appear to appreciate having two good teachers, as some of the white schools seem to have difficulty in this respect. At the Massett Reserve we have not been so fortunate, as to date we have not got a Senior teacher, but Mrs. Fray has her junior room going with 49 pupils up to this time, no doubt there will be many more when the Indians are all back on the Reserve. Mrs. Fray however is able to cope with any increases, and the children are very orderly under her care.

Mrs. McMahon is a widow with a son six years of age who will no doubt attend the junior room of the Skidegate School with the approval of the Department.

I wrote you on September 4th, saying that we had sent the nomination of Miss Betty Jane Chinnick to the Department, subject to your approval. Now we find that, in conference with Rev. H.E. Mr. Affleck; but I am afraid they would not consider the possibility of her going to any other school in British Columbia. I need hardly say again how much we appreciate your co-operation. If this matter can be arranged, will you please send me a wire - c/o General Council, The United Church of Canada, Erskine-American Church, Montreal, where I shall be for the next ten days.

AIRMAIL:

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to your telegram concerning the possible appointment of a teacher to the Skidegate Indian Day School, at present there is no vacancy at this school, as Miss Chinnick's reappointment was authorized in your letter dated August 22nd, your file 157-11-1 W.T. However, we do require two teachers for the Massett Indian Day School, which is in the same area. This school is located about two miles from the white settlement of the same name. At present there is no electricity on the reservation, but the Indians are contemplating the installation of a plant. There is also no water system. There is a Superior School in the town of Massett, which will give instruction to pupils up to Grade X and possibly beyond.

A second possibility is to employ the teacher to whom you refer in the Alert Bay Indian Day School when its construction is completed. This school is about a mile from the Provincial Superior School, which also gives instruction up to Grade X. The school and teachorage will be connected to the regular Power Commission Plant which supplies 110 volt 60 cycle current. The Reserve is also equipped with a water system. I may say that it is anticipated that the school will not be ready until January of 1948.

These are the only two possibilities in Protestant schools close enough to a white High School to permit attendance of a student from a Reservation.

D.-M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY
BRITISH COLUMBIA

Skidegate I.R. No. 1

SCHOOL. This two room structure is in fairly good shape but I would point out that it is surmounted by a cupola housing the school bell, flanked on each side by two very low brick chimneys and a wind is liable to carry sparks into the cupola and set fire to the building. (See photograph attached) The building is in fair repair but requires interior and exterior redecoration. The children appear to be somewhat hard on this school and should be checked up by the staff and Agent.

In order to encourage gardening in the village I believe it would be well to fence off part of the school grounds and establish a school garden. It was observed that the Agent had some clearing done behind the school by relief recipients and this work might be extended to putting the grounds in shape next winter. This work could also include graveling of the walks in place of the wooden walks now in place as these are worn out and broken and liable to cause accidents to the children. The school residence was well kept and clean inside but is an old structure.

J. Coleman,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for B.C.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated December 5th, 1940. Re: improvements at Skidegate School and grounds.

With regard to the two very low chimney's at the above school, also at the teachers residence, I would like to recommend that an extension be made out of one eighth of an inch plate welded together, as per attached sketch. I obtained a tender for the three to cost $10.00 each (3 costing $30.00) there would also be the cost of wire for stays, and labour which altogether should not cost above $45.00 for the three chimney's, the extension would be about 5ft.

A brick extension of 5ft on each chimney would cost in the neighbourhood of $25.00 each chimney and would also have to have iron stays made to hold against the wind storms; it is difficult to get materials for the above, and bricklayers are very scarce, perhaps I could get a tender for the above work, if this is desired.

With regard to fencing off a part of the school ground for gardening to encourage the children, I took this matter up with the Council, and it was their opinion that a fence would not last long owing to the cattle roaming around, and that the most of the children go away with their parents to the canneries etc. from time to time. I have had the teachers (residence) fence repaired several times, but have come to the conclusion that it is better to leave it open, the children too are very destructive, and on my recent visit I cautioned both classes against this practice, and also advised the teachers to check the pupils from time to time.

The Secretary.
The matter of getting relief recipients to work graveling the walks to the entrance and back entrance of the school was taken up with the Council, the only persons on relief are the aged, sick, and T.B., the Indians usually give two days work each in the spring; this is for road improvements and cleaning up the Reserve, it was felt that the Department should take the responsibility of graveling of the above walks to the school, it would cost for hire of truck to haul gravel, and to spread same on walks, about $30.00, this would be from road to front Entrance, and from back entrance to boys & girls toilets.

Your obedient servant,

I beg to advise that I found it necessary to purchase a cook stove and pipes, costing $57.46, f.o.b. Vancouver, for the above-noted school.

Miss Mackie, the teacher of the Junior Division of the School, explained that a stove was necessary both for cooking and for providing additional heat in the cottage. Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ontario.

I wish to submit a brief resume of my recent trip to Prince Rupert and The Queen Charlotte Islands.

XX

QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY

Skidegate

Mr. Phillips accompanied me to Skidegate where a meeting was held with the council and visits made to the day school and some of the Indian homes. While here I also called on Mrs. Gladstone, our field matron, and the local United Church Missionary, the Rev. Mr. Affleck. The meeting with the council was on the whole quite satisfactory and matters on which information was requested were dealt with, these having mainly to do with medical service, preparation of income tax returns and the Indian Day School. No requests for relief were submitted nor complaints made against the Agent.

Certain improvements and repairs to the day school building are necessary and some work is also required to the teacher's residence. I instructed the Agent to prepare a list of these needs and secure an estimate of the costs involved in order that if possible some of the repairs could be undertaken during the months of July and August. The teacher's residence is a large, poorly constructed building and, in my opinion, should not have been acquired by the Department. It will be costly to maintain properly and it might be better to either dispose of it or tear it down and build a smaller new house in replacement as the cost of remodelling would probably equal the cost of a suitable new building. A small new teacher's residence for this Reserve might be included in our post-war program of worthwhile works.

It is doubtful if Miss Mackie, principal of the Indian day school, will continue at Skidegate after the close of the current school year as she is not enjoying good health and has been advised by the doctor to take a year's rest. Miss Mackie had done excellent work for use at Skidegate and is highly esteemed by the Indian people. It will be extremely difficult to replace her. She assured me, however, that she would be glad to seek employment with us should she decide to resume teaching on regaining her health.

(over)
REPORT ON QUEEN CHARLOTTE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JULY, 1944.

At the Skidegate Reserve which I visited during the month, I visited the school and teachery, checked up delivery of paint for school, and found a shortage which was located at the Wharf and delivered. I measured up lot at teachery for lumber for a proposed new fence, interviewed the Field Matron, Dr. McColl, Indians at the Office, also held a Council meeting when matters pertaining to the welfare of the Village were taken up, I visited several homes on the Reserve, and work is progressing on two new five roomed houses in the Village, also several new boat houses have been erected, many boats were anchored in the Village, owing to bad weather.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.

EDUCATION: Both the Massett and Skidegate Schools have been painted inside and outside, new wood shed, toilets, and urinal have been built (or nearly completed) at the Massett School. New wood shed and toilet have been built at the teahery and new furniture and alterations for the comfort of our teachers. At the Skidegate Reserve a new urinal is being built, and also a new fence is being built at the teahery. There is no doubt that the Indian schools are the best on the Islands; the Indians children of this Agency are very bright, and several are now attending superior schools here. The children are exceptionally good at needle work, drawing, painting and very musical. The parents are very keen on giving their children a good education. We are not equipped for Manual training, but have a large class room for this purpose at the Massett school as soon as conditions permit an instructor for that work. Basket making also Slate Totem pole Carving was taught at both schools, but this was stopped at the beginning of the war. Several Indian drawings and designs have been entered in a competition at the Stanford University, U.S.A. We have not as yet heard the result of judges. I usually visit the Massett School three times a month and the Skidegate twice a month. Junior Red Cross work is being carried on at both schools. The Massett school has been adopted by the Sir James Barrie Imperial Daughters of the Empire, from which sporting goods etc. have been received for the pupils.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.

I have the honour to report as follows for the Queen Charlotte Agency, B.C. for the Quarter ending SEPTEMBER, 1946.

GENERAL ADMINISTRATOR

During the past quarter I have paid my usual visits to the Skidegate Reserve each month, spending two days each trip on the Reserve. Owing to the majority of Councillors being off the Reserve, no Council meetings were held, but matters pertaining to the welfare of the Village were taken up with those individual Councillors who happened to be on the Reserve. I visited the school twice each visit, had new heaters installed in both class rooms, had rooms scrubbed out, and minor repairs attended to both at the school and teachers residence, the teachers being supplied with household necessities. I also interviewed several Indians on the Reserve and at the Office, re: trap lines, Allowances, Birth Registrations etc., gave Indians trap-line sketches of their trap-lines to take with them when trapping. I also visited the Massett Reserve several times each month, visiting the school and teachers residence, had two new heaters installed in both class rooms at the school, and attended to minor repairs, and cleaning up. All the wood (fuel) has been delivered and stacked at both the Massett and Skidegate schools and teachers residences, several matter were taken up with the Massett Councillors pertaining to the welfare of the village, the majority of the Indians are still away from the above Reserves, but are expected back about October 30th.

I have your letter of April 12th with regard to janitor service at the Masset Indian Day School for acknowledgement. This building, although not new, is in fair condition and with minor repairs additional equipment and a third teacher (kindergarten) could become one of the finest day schools in the district. In the near future, after the School Inspector's visit, I shall submit several suggestions with regard to these matters for consideration by the Department.

The question at present is that of satisfactory janitor service. The man who had been engaged for this work had very poor vision and could not satisfactorily perform his duties. At present, due to fishing operations and the small remuneration paid for such work, it has been impossible to engage another man. The teachers have taken over the duties for the balance of the term.

However, it is not, in my estimation, fair to expect Day School Teachers to be burdened with janitor work in addition to their teaching and supervising duties.

In a school of this type, janitor's duties should include lighting of fires each morning, sweeping, dusting, washing and oiling of floors when necessary, inspection and cleaning of outside toilets and general supervision of the upkeep of the building.

It is obvious that no person will assume these duties for the remuneration offered of $12.00 monthly, which sum works out, on the basis of an average of 21 teaching days per month, at fifty-seven cents per day.
I would suggest, that since similar conditions exist at the S kidegate Indian Day School, where $10.00 monthly is paid, the entire janitor situation be revised with the object in mind of obtaining satisfactory janitor service for which a decent remuneration be paid.

I would recommend that a man willing to assume the duties as mentioned be paid at minimum rate of $25.00 per month. No doubt if this were approved, suitable janitors could be obtained.

The matter of ventilation has been investigated and several of the windows have been loosened to allow them to be opened providing proper ventilation.

Advice and decision in the matter of janitor service will be appreciated.

J.A. Findlay,
Acting Indian Agent.
Further to my letter of May 2nd, 1947 with reference to the teachers' residence at Skidegate Reserve, I have recently returned from a patrol to that village and submit a report herewith.

When visiting Skidegate six or seven years ago, I had occasion to be in the teachers' residence and was amazed at the poor condition of the home at that time. Seemingly very little has been done over the years to make it habitable or in any way comfortable during the cold weather.

In order to give you as clear as possible a word picture of the building, I am stating the following facts as I found them.

1. Building is of frame construction, very old, with a fancy tower construction at one corner of the roof.
2. The building is out of line.
3. Roof: Minor repairs have been made from time to time, but it still leaks. The shingles are in poor condition and should all be replaced.
4. Walls: Single wall only. Siding was nailed to studs and inside wall board nailed to studs. There is no subfloor lining in the walls either inside or out. Wallboard being on studs only is bulging which condition also exist with the ceiling.
5. Floors: Living room has double flooring and is in good condition, except that the floor slopes to rear of house. Upstairs floor sags and when anyone walks in any room the house vibrates.
6. Stairs: These are dangerous—poorly constructed and one steps sideways from the top step to the upstairs landing.
7. Interior Decorating: Very poor in general and should be renewed for entire house.
8. Windows: All windows are loose. Frames are bad and in some cases collapsing. Wind drives in between frames and walls. Window glass is needed in some windows and putty in all.
9. Doors: As a result of the house being out of line, the doors are off balance and will not close securely.

10. Foundation: Posts in poor condition; ends of some rotten and giving away. Complete new foundation needed.

11. Steps: Front and back steps and verandah will have to be replaced.

The house is extremely cold and without a doubt whatsoever is a fire-trap. Miss Mackie, one of the teachers, who has served faithfully at Skidegate for seven or eight years, definitely states that should she leave the service this year, it will be because of the living conditions. She cannot bear it any longer and I must say I sympathize with her in what she has had to suffer though—extremely uncomfortable living quarters.

My survey of the building indicates the following necessary repairs:

1. New foundations (posts and sills) well braced.
2. Removal of all wallboard lining and partitions. Shiplap lining spoiled and replacement of wallboard in good condition and new sections where needed.
3. Stairs removed.
4. Window frames replaced where necessary—all windows repaired.
5. Front and back steps removed. (renewed)
6. Doors hung properly.
7. Roof renewed and it is suggested that the unsightly tower construction be removed.
8. Complete new interior decoration.

It is obvious from the condition of the building that unforeseen repairs might be necessary once the above suggested repairs were started. Thus I would hesitate to make any estimate of costs without first getting the advice of some building contractor.

Immediately adjacent to the present ten-acreage, is a partially complete new house being constructed by a Skidegate Indian. I was not able to contact the owner on my recent visit but the house is the type ideally suited as a teacher's residence. If the owner would consider selling and the Department buying, the amount of money necessary to effect the repairs to the old building would be more than sufficient to complete it. This matter will be investigated further on my next visit to Skidegate.
In any event no repairs could be effected until after the close of the present school term and even then, at the height of the fishing season, it will be difficult to obtain labor.

I may say that the conditions under which the Skidegate teachers are living, sets no example to the natives in the matter of decent homes.

There is a building contractor at Massett who will, if requested, go with me to Skidegate and make a more complete survey of the necessary repairs and will submit an estimate of costs. At the same time he could place a value on the unfinished house referred to above. Expenses in this matter will incur only hotel charges while at Skidegate.

If the Department concurs in this suggestion, a vote to that effect will be appreciated.

J.A. Findlay,
Acting Indian Agent.

I have to refer to your letter of May 12th to the Department in reply to Mr. Neary's letter of April 11th in connection with the teachers' residence at Skidegate. Contrary to the conclusion reached by you with respect to lack of maintenance since your visit to Skidegate six years ago, our records indicate that various expenditures have been made from time to time, particularly within the last two years, to make this building more comfortable, and there is nothing in our records to indicate that any request for funds for maintenance or improvement to the building was ever refused.

There is nothing in this office to show whether the building in question is the property of the Department or the United Church, although I am inclined to think that it belongs to the latter, in which case if conditions are as bad as your report indicates it is doubtful if the Department would be justified in making any large expenditures for repairs.

It is noted that there is a building contractor at Massett who will, if requested, go to Skidegate with you and make a complete survey of repairs necessary to the residence and at the same time place a valuation on the unfinished Indian house which you consider might be suitable for a teachers' residence. You may arrange with him to make the necessary inspection on the understanding that the only cost to the Dept. will be hotel charges while at Skidegate.
It is noted that in any event no repairs could be effected until after the close of the present school term which will give you time to make a further investigation and to report to this office, advising at the same time if the present teacher's residence is the property of the Department or the Church.

I may say that the question of repairs to departmental buildings is one which should be dealt with through this office.

D. M. MacKay,

Dear Sir,

Re: Residence for Nurse and Teacher, Skidegate.

Replying to your letter 157-11-8, Dec 29th, I beg to report that the house secured for the teacher and nurse at Skidegate is one which originally belonged to a mining company who had a lease from the Ban near the village. In default of payment, the Council took possession of the house and moved it onto the Reserve. This was done several years ago. Miss Andrews lived in it for a time. It is a two-room frame building 22x14', and is not satisfactory as a permanent residence. The Council is putting on a lean-to, laying on the water and making it as comfortable as possible. The two doors mentioned in my estimates for repairs etc will not be charged to the Department, as the Council is standing all expenses regarding repairs. The Council will rent this house for ten dollars ($10.00) per month, and keep it in repair. After a suitable house is provided for the teacher and nurse, I would recommend that the Department still rent this house as an office and living quarters for the agent when at Skidegate. It is very unsatisfactory to have to do all business in private houses, etc. at present.

Regarding a permanent residence for the teacher and nurse, the Skidegate Council ask that their Trust fund be used for this purpose, and that they rent the house to the Department for Twenty Dollars ($20.00) per month, to be paid to the Treasurer of the Council each month. The Council would be responsible for the upkeep and repairs. This meets with the approval of the whole village. If the Department agrees to this, I would appreciate having an early reply, so that the house could be built before all the villagers scatter for the fishing about May.

Your obedient servant,

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary, Indian Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

When at Skidegate recently, I interviewed the new teacher, Miss Wright. She is an elderly lady, and seems rather eccentric. She refuses to share a room with any other person. She is at present living in the house which Miss Macrae and Mrs. Gladstone occupied. There is only one bedroom and medicines are also kept in the same room. The clergyman, Mr. Matthews does not care to board the teacher. When the new Nurse arrives, there will be the question of accommodation. There is, however, a suitable house in the village which can be purchased for $1200.00. This house is in good condition. Only one bedroom is completed, but another one could be finished off, and other work such as boarding in around the foundation, and a room finished as a dispensary, for approximately $50.00 for labour and material. This would give six rooms, which would accommodate both the Teacher and Nurse. I asked Messrs Mitchell and Currie, who built the Massett School, for an estimate on a suitable house for two people, and they gave the figure, $800.00. The house mentioned above, would also be large enough to accommodate an extra teacher when required. It is owned by an Indian by the name of James McKay, and is in a good location, close to the School. I would recommend that this house be purchased.

Memorandum:

For some time the Department has been renting a residence for the teacher at the Skidegate Indian Day School. When a nurse was appointed for this reserve, she lived with the teacher; but the arrangement was unsatisfactory, as the house was too small. In January of this year, the Indian Band requested the Department to use their Trust Funds for the erection of a residence for the teacher and the nurse and to allow the Band $20 per month rental. This suggestion was not approved, and the Department informed Indian Agent Gillett that we would try to secure an appropriation for the purpose of erecting a suitable residence for these workers.

Miss Wright, the present school teacher, is no longer young and is a little eccentric, according to Mr. Gillett. She, apparently, refuses to share a room with any other person. Mr. Gillett recommends that we purchase a residence erected in 1914 on the reserve, which is for sale. The price is $1200 and, with another $250, it can be finished, decorated and prepared as a residence for the two workers and as a dispensary. Blue prints of this building have been forwarded and Mr. Orr and myself wish to recommend that purchase be made. Funds can be found at the present time from this year's appropriation.

Ottawa 2nd January, 1926.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, with which you submitted a voucher for $50.00 for rent of house for the teacher and nurse at Skidegate, and in reply I have to inform you that the amount in question has been placed to the credit of the Receiver General for the Skidegate Band.

With reference to the cost of repairs which the Skidegate Council had made to the building, I beg to say that certified accounts covering the same may be submitted by you to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Revd J. Gillett,
Indian Agent,
Masset,
B.C.
Dear Sir,

I enclose herewith Voucher No. 362 for rental for the house occupied by the teacher and nurse, at Skidegate. I would suggest that the cheque be sent direct to the Skidegate Council, for they went to considerable expense to put the house in good condition before renting it to the Department. They spent one hundred and twenty-four dollars for this, according to their books, which I audited recently. Perhaps the best plan would be to have this rent paid into the trust fund as before, and then have the Council submit a bill for the full amount spent. Kindly advise.

I hope the teacher will be able to move into the new quarters, by January.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
